No new policy. Continuing policy in Western Australia and Tasmania still has mask requirements.   WA anyone aged 12 years and over must wear a face mask in:  - Hospitals and health care settings including: GPs, Aboriginal health services, Dental and optical health clinics, Allied health services such as physiotherapy, radiology and occupational therapy services  - Aged care facilities, residential care facilities including disability service facilities and mental health residential facilities  - Public and passenger transport, including school buses, taxis and rideshare vehicles  - Correctional facilities  - Aircraft  Masks are encouraged where physical distancing is not possible.     Tasmania:   Anyone aged 12 years and over must wear a face mask in the following indoor areas â unless theyâre exempt:  - aboard aircraft  - all close contacts when outside their home â unless theyâre exempt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220712102242/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/covid-19-coronavirus/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do  https://archive.ph/xVoyd

No new policy. Continuing from 31 March health measures are at Level 1 (Western Australia region).  Masks are required for people aged 8 years and over (year 3 and over for schools):  - everywhere indoors, other than in the home  - when on public transport, in taxis and rideshare vehicles  - at hospitals and residential aged care or residential disability care facilities.  https://archive.ph/uBFBe

No new policy. Continuing policy from 29 April in Western Australia include external visitor restrictions for residential aged and disability care facilities (same as previous threat levels):  - 2 visitors permitted per resident patient per day  - Masks must be worn by staff and visitors indoors and outdoors  - Proof of vaccination applies for visitors    National policy still in place outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220712102242/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/covid-19-coronavirus/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do  https://web.archive.org/web/20220322082432/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

Brunei has returned to in-person teaching for most levels (except primary schools), after schools were moved online after the surge in Covid-19 cases due to the Omicron wave. However, given the rollout of the vaccination programme for age 5-11 in Brunei, it will allow primary schools to reopen on May 14 (as reported by the Star)    As previously reported by the Scoop,    'Child care centres, kindergartens, secondary schools, religious schools, colleges and sixth form centres will resume classroom learning on either April 4 or 5, pending the sighting of the moon this Friday which will determine the first day of Ramadan.    However only primary schools with less than 50 pupils â such as those in rural areas â will be allowed to reopen, while the rest must wait until the government kicks off its COVID-19 vaccination programme for children aged 5-11.    Face-to-face learning has been suspended since March 7 after schools reported low attendance at the height of the Omicron surge.    Before retuning to classrooms, the minister urged parents to conduct ART testing on their children twice a week and to regularly report their results to the school.    âIf there are any students experiencing symptoms such as a cold or cough, we hope parents or guardians can send them to the clinic for treatment and not send them to school.â    He added that adolescents aged 12 to 17 who are not yet vaccinated will be allowed to return to schools next week, rescinding a previous policy which did not allow unvaccinated children to attend in-person classes.    This recent announcement brings to an end the third school closure since the pandemic started. The first suspension of classroom learning lasted from March 26, 2020 to June 2, 2020, while the second closure spanned August 9, 2021 to January 2, 2022.'    See the Scoop's report, entitled "Schools to resume face-to-face learning next week", archived at https://archive.ph/ElXxD  See the Star's report, entitled "Brunei: May 14 back to school for children 5-11 years old, says education minister", archived at https://archive.ph//NJhiZ

As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 17 June, foreigners are now allowed.    According the the Prime Minister Office's statement dated 09 June, from 15 June onwards, pre-departure swab tests for inbound travellers are no longer required regardless of vaccination status, and fully vaccinated travellers are no longer required to undergo ART testing and self-isolation upon arrival in the country.    Travellers who have not completed the COVID-19 vaccination are required to undergo ART testing upon arrival, with three days of self-isolation and will only be released if tested negative with a PCR test on day three.    Cross-border travel via land and seaports will also be allowed for essential reasons, with an intention to fully open cross-border travel from 01 August.    See the Prime Minister Office's statement, dated 09 June, archived at https://archive.ph/cMzbN  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.ph/2zJhM

Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July 2021. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    Vaccinations have also been rolled out to adolescents aged 12 to 17 from November 8, utilising the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. This has been extended to children ages 5â11 from 03 April 2022.    Booster shots have been available to the general public since 17 December. Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs." Education Bureau announces latest anti-epidemic measures for schools    The spokesman added, "As for the daily rapid antigen test (RAT) arrangement, taking into account the implementation of relevant arrangements in schools since the resumption of face-to-face classes and the number of cases reported by schools to the CHP, we have observed that the RAT at this stage can help gatekeeping in schools. After listening to views of the CHP, it is considered necessary for schools to maintain the daily RAT arrangement until late June. The EDB will continue to distribute RAT kits to students with financial needs through schools. The Government will review the development of the epidemic in a timely manner and consider later whether to adjust the daily RAT arrangement."    https://web.archive.org/web/20220616100646/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202205/19/P2022051900672.htm?fontSize=1

A spokesman for the EDB said, "To ensure the safety and health of students, the EDB has earlier required all teachers, school staff and students to complete an RAT every school day and obtain a negative test result before returning to school for work or lessons. The spokesman for the EDB reminded, "As the epidemic situation shows signs of a rebound, schools must continue to strictly put in place various anti-epidemic measures stipulated in the 'Health Protection Measures for Schools' issued by the EDB and the 'Health Advice to Schools for the Prevention of COVID-19' issued by the CHP, as well as all other measures against the pandemic."    https://archive.ph/Xj46n

No new policy found    (4) Bars / pubs will remain closed during the period of May 5 to May 18; and during the period of May 19 to June 1 may open from 5am to 1.59am of the subsequent day with a maximum number of four persons per table and restriction of patrons to 75 per cent of their capacity.  Live performance and dancing activity are not allowed therein.     (5) Other requirements and restrictions on catering premises and bars / pubs upon re-opening will continue to remain in force, including that all customers, when they are away from the table, must not consume food or drink and must wear a mask, and they must scan the âLeaveHomeSafeâ venue QR code using the âLeaveHomeSafeâ mobile application on their mobile phones / other mobile devices before entering the premises (excluding persons who only order takeaway).  Operators of catering premises and bars / pubs are required to use the mobile application provided by the Government to scan the QR code of a patronâs vaccination record, medical exemption certificate or recovery record.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220616150255/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202205/04/P2022050300895.htm

The spokesman reminded operators of bars/pubs, other catering premises, and relevant scheduled premises to stay vigilant, and strictly comply with the requirements and directions under the Prevention and Control of Disease (Vaccine Pass) Regulation (Cap. 599L) and the Prevention and Control of Disease (Requirements and Directions) (Business and Premises) Regulation (Cap. 599F), etc., including the latest requirement on rapid antigen test (RAT).   The spokesman reiterated that the new requirement on RAT result has already come into effect. Before a patron enters a bar/pub, club/nightclub or bar/pub zone of catering premises, he/she must present photo of a negative RAT result obtained within 24 hours before entry.     https://archive.ph/z9KEc  https://archive.ph/jJ74m

The venue manager for bars or pubs should put up a notice showing the scope of the premises, venue manager for catering premises with bars or pubs should put up a notice showing the floor plan of the relevant part of the premises.    https://archive.ph/jJ74m

(13) Unless exempted, group gatherings of more than four persons in public places will remain prohibited. The requirement is also applicable to group gatherings in catering premises, bars / pubs and scheduled premises regulated under Cap. 599F in which the relevant requirements or restrictions are not complied with.     (14) Subject to relevant requirements, local group tours with no more than 30 persons may continue to be conducted.  The relevant requirements include (1) relevant staff has received three doses of vaccine, and conducted a rapid antigen test (RAT) on the same day before the commencement of local group tour activities; and (2) all tour participants have fulfilled the prevailing Vaccine Pass requirements.  If all tour participants have conducted RAT on the same day before the commencement of local group tour activities, the relevant restriction on the number of participants will be relaxed to 100 persons.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220616150255/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202205/04/P2022050300895.htm

The Government gazetted the specifications that, during the 14-day period from June 30 to July 13, 2022:  unless exempted, the prohibition on group gatherings of more than four persons in public places will continue. The requirement is also applicable to group gatherings in catering business and scheduled premises regulated under Cap. 599F in which the relevant requirements or restrictions are not complied with.  Local group tours with no more than 30 persons organised by licensed travel agents and registered with the Travel Industry Council of Hong Kong may be resumed. The relevant requirements include (1) relevant staff has received three doses of vaccine, and conducted RAT on the same day before the commencement of local group tour activities; and (2) all tour participants have fulfilled the prevailing Vaccine Pass requirements. If all tour participants have conducted RAT on the same day before the commencement of local group tour activities, the relevant restriction on the number of participants will be relaxed to 100 persons.    https://archive.ph/jJ74m

Is public transportation operating?  Yes    (12) Under Cap. 599I, if a person does not wear a mask in accordance with the requirement, an authorised person may deny that person from boarding a public transport carrier or entering the area concerned, as well as require that person to wear a mask and disembark from the carrier or leave the said area.  A person in contravention of the relevant provision commits an offence and the maximum penalty is a fine at level 3 ($10,000). In addition, authorised public officers may issue penalty notices to persons who do not wear a mask in accordance with the requirement and such persons may discharge liability for the offence by paying a fixed penalty at $5,000.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220616150255/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202205/04/P2022050300895.htm

If you are not fully vaccinated and have visited places outside mainland China, Macao or Taiwan within the past 14 days, you will be denied entry into Hong Kong.    All travellers ending their journey at Hong Kong International Airport will have to undergo a PCR test and rapid antigen test for coronavirus. Travellers will be required to remain at the airport whilst awaiting the results of the rapid antigen test. Further information is available on the Centre for Health Protectionâs website.    If you test positive, the Hong Kong authorities will arrange for admission to a public hospital or isolation facility. If you are deemed to be a contact of a positive case, you may be placed in a Hong Kong government quarantine centre for a minimum of 7 days. All arrivals including those who test negative for coronavirus need to undergo 7-day compulsory quarantine in a designated hotel. See âQuarantine requirementsâ below.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220616153045/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hong-kong/entry-requirements

You can purchase RAT kits for voluntary testing. There is sufficient supply in the market, so please do not hoard.     The Government is distributing free RAT kits to the following groups of people:    Specified high-risk and target groups â through their respective industry associations/ government departments.  Residents undergoing "StayHomeSafe" â are provided with RAT kits as part of the supplies they receive.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220616154439/https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/rat/eng/rat.html

For "early identification, early isolation and early treatmentâ, the Government is procuring Rapid Antigen Test (RAT) kits in bulk for various groups of people for testing. The objective is to identify those who have been infected and sever transmission chains at the earliest possible time.  An RAT is designed to directly detect SARS-CoV-2 virus proteins (antigens) in respiratory specimens. It is intended for qualitative detection of antigens in specimens from individuals with suspected infections. As such, it should be used in conjunction with the results of clinical interpretation and other laboratory tests. Different brands of tests are available in the market. Most of them require nasal or nasopharyngeal swab samples or deep throat saliva samples. The test is easy to perform.  RAT kits are also generally available for voluntary testing.     https://archive.ph/TywUD

Hong Kongâs Covid contact-tracing app has begun flagging users who havenât uploaded vaccination records, as the city struggles to contain a resurgent outbreak thatâs taxing its health system.    The LeaveHomeSafe app -- mandatory for entrance to many restaurants and other public venues -- was updated over the weekend and now flashes a red QR code on its check-in page for users that havenât linked to an official immunization record.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220616155103/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=1ffedfaa-ed8c-11ec-bd87-47564c466970&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMi0wMi0yMS9ob25nLWtvbmctcy1jb250YWN0LXRyYWNpbmctYXBwLW5vdy1mbGFncy11bnZhY2NpbmF0ZWQtdXNlcnM=

Pursuant to the directions issued under Cap. 599F, all customers/users/visitors must scan the âLeaveHomeSafeâ venue QR code using the âLeaveHomeSafeâ mobile application on his/her mobile phone/other mobile device.  Relevant requirement  applies to all catering premises and scheduled premises subject to such directions, including all catering premises providing dine-in services, bars/pubs, bathhouses, party rooms, clubs/nightclubs, karaoke establishments, mahjong-tin kau premises, cruise ships, amusement game centres, fitness centres, places of amusement, places of public entertainment, beauty parlours, massage establishments, club-houses, sports premises, swimming pools, hotels and guesthouses, event premises, religious premises, shopping malls, department stores, supermarkets, markets and barber shops or hair salons.    https://archive.ph/2DKWw

(III) Mask-wearing requirement     (11) Starting from May 5, the mandatory mask-wearing requirement under the Prevention and Control of Disease (Wearing of Mask) Regulation (Cap. 599I) will be relaxed.  A person must wear a mask all the time when the person is boarding or on board a public transport carrier, is entering or present in an MTR paid area, or is entering or present in a specified public place.  Citizens are allowed not to wear masks if they are present in outdoor public places in country parks and special areas as defined in section 2 of the Country Parks Ordinance (Cap. 208)), or conducting strenuous physical activity (e.g. exercising or jogging) in outdoor public places.     (12) Under Cap. 599I, if a person does not wear a mask in accordance with the requirement, an authorised person may deny that person from boarding a public transport carrier or entering the area concerned, as well as require that person to wear a mask and disembark from the carrier or leave the said area.  A person in contravention of the relevant provision commits an offence and the maximum penalty is a fine at level 3 ($10,000). In addition, authorised public officers may issue penalty notices to persons who do not wear a mask in accordance with the requirement and such persons may discharge liability for the offence by paying a fixed penalty at $5,000.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220616150255/https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202205/04/P2022050300895.htm

Citizens are allowed not to wear masks if they are present in outdoor public places in country parks and special areas as defined in section 2 of the Country Parks Ordinance (Cap. 208)), or conducting strenuous physical activity (e.g. exercising or jogging) in outdoor public places. To safeguard public health and to allow the resuming of normal activities of society gradually, the Government is implementing a territory-wide COVID-19 Vaccination Programme (the âProgrammeâ) free of charge for all Hong Kong residents.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220601082754/https://www.covidvaccine.gov.hk/en/programme

To safeguard public health and to allow the resuming of normal activities of society gradually, the Government is implementing a territory-wide COVID-19 Vaccination Programme (the âProgrammeâ) free of charge for all Hong Kong residents.  The Government sets up CVCs in various districts in Hong Kong providing vaccination service to the public, including BioNTech vaccine for persons aged 12 or above and Sinovac vaccine for persons aged 3 or above. Only one type of vaccine will normally be administered in a CVC.    https://archive.ph/3waGu

The Social Welfare Department today announced that a restricted visiting arrangement for residential care homes (RCHs) for the elderly and people with disabilities will be implemented from May 13.    Under the new arrangement, visitors, except for official visitors, must have received at least two doses of a COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days before their visits and present such records to the RCHs. They must also present proof that they have obtained a negative result from a COVID-19 rapid antigen test (RAT) conducted at the designated area of the RCHs prior to the visit.    If either the visitor or the resident concerned have not received a COVID-19 vaccine due to health reasons with written proof provided by doctors, they must obtain a negative result from a nucleic acid test for the virus within 48 hours as well as a negative RAT result conducted at the designated area in the RCHs before the visit.    The residents concerned must have received at least two doses of a COVID-19 vaccine, or show written proof provided by a doctor that they have not received a vaccine due to health reasons.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220616161245/https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2022/05/20220506/20220506_214727_488.html

Coded 1G for the period 22â27 June 2022. Schools have been allowed to resume in-person classes, but with health protocols in place such as reduced capacity, social distancing and other health measures, in addition to compulsory wearing of facemasks. Have not found evidence of mandatory closures or partial closures of certain levels of schooling.      A.	Indonesia uses a tiered system to determine COVID-19 restrictions (PPKM Levels 1â4 from least to most restrictive.) For period of 22â27 June 2022, vast majority of the country was at PPKM Level 1, as per Indonesiaâs COVID-19 Task Force Maps. [Language: English]    1.	22 June 2022 (see pages 4â9) https://web.archive.org/web/20220627223500/https://covid19.go.id/storage/app/media/Penanganan%20COVID-19/2022/Juni/20220622-eng-ver-update-percepatan-penanganan-covid-19-di-indonesia.pdf   2.	27 June 2022 (see pages 4â9) https://web.archive.org/web/20220627144008/https:/covid19.go.id/storage/app/media/Penanganan%20COVID-19/2022/Juni/20220627-eng-ver-update-percepatan-penanganan-covid-19-di-indonesia.pdf     B.	Govt had earlier announced on 11 May 2022 schools in regions with PPKM Levels 1â3 could open for in-person classes, and at 100% capacity, but with health protocols in place, such reduced capacity in common areas like the canteen, surveillance and monitoring of school clusters, having activities carried out in well-ventilated areas outdoors.      Additional note: Govt policy also ties the capacity permitted in schools for in-person classes also to vaccination rate of the surrounding area and the elderly.    1.	[Bahasa Indonesia]: âMinistry of Health: Schools in Regions at PPKM Levels 1-3 to Carry Out Face-to-Face Classes at 100% Capacityâ: https://web.archive.org/web/20220630073102/https://www.kompas.com/edu/read/2022/05/11/183214271/kemendikbud-sekolah-wilayah-ppkm-1-3-wajib-ptm-100-persen-setiap-hari?page=all     2. Note about difference from previous coding; review may be required as vaccine-differentiation policy for some workplaces appears to have been in effect earlier.     Coded 2G/1T for 22â27 June 2022.     -	2G for unvaccinated because proof of vaccination for entry is mandatory for some sectors all across the country.     -	1T for vaccinated is primarily due to a small area (Teluk Bintuni) in the province of *West Papua*, where even vaccinated people are subject to capacity restrictions, as strictest measure is coded for. In rest of the country, mostly no capacity restrictions if vaccinated (i.e 0 type of coding).     Policies currently consist of two levels:      I. Proof of vaccination (via showing a âgreenâ status on IDN governmentâs Pedulilindungi app) required to enter some workplaces.     II. Percentage capacity allowed also determined by the âPPKM Levelâ classification of a region. PPKM Levels run from 1â4 (also coded green, yellow, orange and red), from least to most restrictions.     A. 	Explanation of how Pedulilindungi app is used to verify vaccination status:    -	[English] "Wonderful Indonesia"â Indonesian Ministry of Tourism site: http://web.archive.org/web/20220703134041/https://www.indonesia.travel/gb/en/trip-ideas/a-brief-guide-on-using-peduli-lindungi-mobile-app     â[T]his mobile app will provide color-coded information regarding the COVID-19 status of the users. Black means infected, red means unvaccinated, yellow means vaccinated for the first dose, and green means completely vaccinatedâ¦ PeduliLindungi mobile app can also store the userâs digital COVID-19 vaccination and COVID-19 test certificates.â    B. 	Current situation:     Vast majority of Indonesia is presently at PPKM Level 1, which allows for 100% capacity, but this is *conditional* on showing proof of vaccination in some workplace sectors.     Only one small region (Teluk Bintuni) in West Papua (âPapua Baratâ) is at PPKM Level 2. PPKM Level 2 requires reduced capacity (depending on sector) *and* proof of vaccination for some workplaces.     Current PPKM Level designations will last from *7 June 2022* to *4 July 2022*, before it is reviewed, as per COVID-19 task force map: (see pages 4â9 for the map):     https://web.archive.org/web/20220627144008/https:/covid19.go.id/storage/app/media/Penanganan%20COVID-19/2022/Juni/20220627-eng-ver-update-percepatan-penanganan-covid-19-di-indonesia.pdf     **Note:** Subsequent updates should check updated task force maps, which are published in the regular COVID-19 situation reports from the IDN government. Website is in Bahasa, but English PDF versions are available for those updates labelled âUPDATE PENANGANAN COVID-19â when the link is entered.    COVID-19 situation reports found here: http://web.archive.org/web/20220704050554/https://covid19.go.id/penanganan-kesehatan     C. 	Sources showing details of PPKM restrictions + requirement of vaccination (showing âgreenâ on the PeduliLindungi app). Exceptions seem to be allowed only for those who are medically unable to be vaccinated.     1. 	National summary of capacity restrictions and vaccination requirements for workplaces, effective from 7 June 2022 (please see page 2 onwards for the table summarising measures for non-education workplaces. West Papua measures are on page 4): [English]    http://web.archive.org/web/20220704035655/https://www.ssek.com/images/Update_on_PPKM_Policy_in_Indonesia_Effective_as_of_June_7_2022.pdf     -	Overall, some slight variation regionally in which workplaces require âGreenâ status for entry (âgreen categorised peopleâ), but examples include hotels not being used for quarantine, stores, shopping malls, restaurants and eateries and cinemas.     2.	Details of PPKM Level 1 restrictions, as announced for June 7âJuly 4 2022 period, showing vaccine requirement for some workplaces.     -	Bali: https://archive.ph/HjvR2#selection-883.0-895.228       -	Jakarta: http://web.archive.org/web/20220704034317/https://corona.jakarta.go.id/en/artikel/catat-ini-peraturan-ppkm-level-1-di-jakarta     âSeveral sectors such as non-quarantine handling hotels, export-oriented industries, energy, logistics, postal, transportation and distribution, food and beverages, fertilizers and petrochemicals, cement and building materials, public infrastructure construction, and basic utilities are required to do screening process to workers and visitors via PeduliLindungi at the entrance and exit doors of the office. Only those who have been vaccinated are allowed to enter.â    âAs usual, visitors and workers of shopping centers/malls/trade centers are required to be screened using the PeduliLindungi application. Only those with the green category in the application may enter the room, unless they cannot be vaccinated for health reasons."    Other sources showing application of vaccine requirements:    1.	[Bahasa Indonesia] (Reported 7 June 2022): https://archive.ph/SAMfQ#selection-2411.0-2449.158     â[Translation from Bahasa] âRestaurants/restaurants, cafes located in buildings/shops or outdoorsâ¦are allowed to open until 22.00 local time to 100% capacityâ¦Meanwhile, during operation, restaurants are required to use the PeduliLindung application to screen all visitors and employees. Only visitors with the Green category in the PeduliLindung application are allowed to enter, except for those who have not been vaccinated for health reasons.â     2. [Bahasa Indonesia] (Reported 7 June 2022): Mention of vaccine requirements for gyms, supermarkets, shopping malls, eateries, cinemas.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220704044647/https://health.detik.com/berita-detikhealth/d-6114069/aturan-ppkm-jawa-bali-level-1-lengkap-wfo-hingga-nge-mal     D.     Earlier examples of vaccine differentiation being reported.     -	16 September 2021: Cinemas      https://archive.ph/Daau5#selection-973.214-973.557    -	13 August 2021: Shopping malls    http://web.archive.org/web/20220704051403/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/indonesia-malls-reopen-exclusively-vaccinated-shoppers-2021-08-13/

Indonesia codes areas under PPKM restrictions. The area under Sorong Regency is under Level 2 restriction until 1 Aug 22. The area Jabodetabek was scheduled to be placed under Level 2 restriction from 5 Jul 22 but was cancelled the next day on 6 Jul 22 (coding not affected as there are still other regions that are under level 2 restriction). The rest of the areas are under level 1 restrictions.     Under level 1 regulation, all in-person workers in non-essential sectors must be vaccinated.   Under level 2 regulation, essential workplaces may continue to operate at 100% capacity with more stringent regulation of operating hours and implementation of health protocols. Activities in the non-essential sector should only operate at 75% maximum capacity. All in-person employees must be vaccinated. Under level 1 regulation, screening necessary for events that exceed 1000 participants  Under level 2 regulation, public facilities and venues must limit the number of their maximum participants (75% capacity)    CNBC Indonesia: https://web.archive.org/web/20220711094836/https://www.cnbcindonesia.com/news/20220705064911-4-352934/ppkm-diperpanjang-1-bulan-jabodetabek-masuk-level-2--lagi-  Sindonews: https://web.archive.org/web/20220711094837/https://nasional.sindonews.com/read/817431/15/ppkm-diperpanjang-hingga-1-agustus-ini-aturan-lengkap-level-1-dan-2-1656979654  SSEK: https://web.archive.org/web/20220711095710/https://www.ssek.com/blog/jakarta-is-at-ppkm-level-1-what-does-it-mean  Bloomberg: https://web.archive.org/web/20220627133204/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-06-21/indonesia-tightens-screening-at-large-events-as-covid-cases-rise

No coding change. Public transport allowed to operate at 100% capacity.     Indonesia uses a tiered system to determine various restrictions. PPKM levels 1â4, colour coded green, yellow, orange and red, from least restrictive to most restrictive COVID-19 measures.     At PPKM levels 1 and 2, public transport is permitted to run at 100% capacity.     - Article from 21 October 2021, explaining public transport capacity rules in relation to PPKM levels [English]:     1.	https://archive.ph/wViQg#selection-1931.2-1931.111     From 22â27 June 2022, vast majority of Indonesian regions are classified PPKM level 1 (green), with just a few regions being level 2 (see pages 4-9). For both levels, 100% capacity is permitted.     - Source: Indonesian government COVID-19 task force reports [English]:     1.	22 June 2022: https://web.archive.org/web/20220627223500/https://covid19.go.id/storage/app/media/Penanganan%20COVID-19/2022/Juni/20220622-eng-ver-update-percepatan-penanganan-covid-19-di-indonesia.pdf    2.	27 June 2022: https://web.archive.org/web/20220627144008/https:/covid19.go.id/storage/app/media/Penanganan%20COVID-19/2022/Juni/20220627-eng-ver-update-percepatan-penanganan-covid-19-di-indonesia.pdf
Public transport at 100% capacity in both Level 1 and Level 2 PPKM regions.     SSEK: https://web.archive.org/web/20220711095710/https://www.ssek.com/blog/jakarta-is-at-ppkm-level-1-what-does-it-mean

No coding change for the period 22â27 June 2022. 2 (unvaccinated) / 0 (vaccinated), due to vaccination requirements:     Proof of vaccination required for domestic travel in Indonesia:    -	Fully-vaccinated adults allowed to travel, with proof of completed vaccination.   -	Partially-vaccinated adults who have taken only 1 dose allowed to travel, but must also take a PCR (up to 72 hours before) or rapid antigen test (up to 24 hours before).   -	Exceptions for unvaccinated are restricted primarily to children below 6 or adults who cannot be vaccinated due to medical reasons (must produce doctorsâ statement).     1. CNBC Indonesia article [22 June 2022] [Bahasa Indonesia]: https://archive.ph/rJJv4#selection-859.0-943.220     4. Domestic flights require proof of vaccination, but not via land travel. Hence coded as 1G for Covid-19 non-vaccinated.   Fully vaccinated travellers only need to provide their proof of vaccination on domestic flights.     Sindonews: https://web.archive.org/web/20220711094837/https://nasional.sindonews.com/read/817431/15/ppkm-diperpanjang-hingga-1-agustus-ini-aturan-lengkap-level-1-dan-2-1656979654US Embassy: https://web.archive.org/web/20220708004623/https://id.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

No policy change for period of 22â27 June 2022. Code 2 (unvaccinated) / 1 (vaccinated.)     Fully-vaccinated travellers do not need to quarantine, but must show proof of vaccination.   Unvaccinated or partially-vaccinated travellers are permitted to enter, but required to 1) Take a PCR test upon arrival 2) Quarantine for 5 x 24 hours. 3) Take another PCR test to exit quarantine. Not possible to skip quarantine by testing negative on the first test.     Note that Indonesiaâs definition of âfully vaccinatedâ requires the 2nd dose to have been taken 14 days ago.     Sources:    1.	Garuda Airlines (IDN national carrier) information page, see under âInternational Flights Entering Indonesiaâ tab [archived 27 June 2022]:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220627114907/https://www.garuda-indonesia.com/jp/en/news-and-events/kebijakan-operasional-terkait-covid19     2.	UK travel advisory for Indonesia [archived 27 June 2022]: https://web.archive.org/web/20220627110849/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/indonesia/entry-requirements     3.	Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs, travel advisory for Indonesia [archived 27 June 2022]: https://archive.ph/IDGSA#selection-1615.0-1615.719

Quarantine period of 5 x 24 hours is needed for international travelers who have not been vaccinated or have received first dose of vaccination of a two-dose vaccination regime. All inbound travelers 6 years and older must be fully vaccinated (complete dose of COVID-19 vaccines, with or without booster) against COVID-19, at least 14 days prior to travel for non-quarantine.  Upon arrival, travelers will complete a COVID-19 symptom check, and temperature check. There is no quarantine requirement for travelers who are fully-vaccinated.     US Embassy: https://web.archive.org/web/20220708004623/https://id.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Note about difference from prior coding: Earlier coding/policy notes may require review, as some major policies seem to be omitted.     For 22â27 June 2022: Coded 2F, mainly for evidence of ongoing policies that provide income support for informal workers. Coded 2 (more than 50%) as per coding advice, because the policies in questions distribute *the same fixed sum* to all eligible recipients, rather than basing it on a percentage of the recipientâs lost income.    Additional note: There is *also* a government policy targeted at *formal workers* earning 3.5 million rupiah or belowâ the âWage Subsidy Assistanceâ scheme (referred to as BSU, or âBantuan Subsidi Upahâ in Bahasa). However, the planned disbursement for 2022 (originally announced in April 2022) is delayed which is why E1 is coded as 2F instead of âall workersâ for the period of 22â27 June 2022.     Subsequent updates should monitor for re-implementation of the BSU / Wage Subsidy Assistance.     A.	Formal Workers     1.	28 June 2022: âMinistry of Manpower explains delay in disbursement of wage subsidies for 2022:â [Bahasa]  http://web.archive.org/web/20220702095934/https://www.tvonenews.com/ekonomi/50263-pencairan-subsidi-upah-tahun-2022-terhambat-ini-penjelasan-kemnaker    2.	26 May 2022: âWorkers have been waiting; when will BSU 2022 be disbursed?â [Bahasa]  http://web.archive.org/web/20220702100124/https://money.kompas.com/read/2022/05/26/155008926/sudah-dinanti-para-pekerja-kapan-bsu-2022-cair    3.	6 April 2022: Indonesian govt announces plan to disburse the wage subsidy again in 2022. [English] http://web.archive.org/web/20220702093128/https://setkab.go.id/en/govt-to-disburse-wage-subsidy-minister-says/     âWhile in 2022, the Government planned to distribute the BSU to workers / laborers who earn a wage of less than Rp 3.5 million. The database of BSU recipients is collected from the database of the Workers Social Security Agency, according to [Minister for Manpower] Ida. The Government will allocate Rp8.8 trillion for the BSU. Every recipient will receive Rp1 million.â     4.	22 July 2021: Earlier Indonesian govt statement explaining the wage subsidy assistance scheme: [English]  http://web.archive.org/web/20220702093128/https://setkab.go.id/en/govt-to-disburse-wage-subsidy-minister-says/    âIn a bid to prevent layoffs due to the impact of COVID-19 pandemic, the Government has decided to continue disbursing wage subsidy for workers/laborers this year. According to Minister of Manpower Ida Fauziyah, this subsidy aims to prevent entrepreneurs from laying off their workers and to give financial support to furloughed workers.â    B.	Informal workers:     Policies consist of direct assistance to:    -	Specific groups of informal workers in certain identified sectors (street vendors, other vendors and fishermen)  -	Multiple other forms of cash support to the poorest families (which likely overlap heavily with other informal workers). Coverage seems wide, govt statistics say disbursement is to millions of households (see source 2 below.)      1.	COVID-19 Task Force Page: âBudget Realization for Handling COVID-19 and National Economic Recovery (PC-PEN) as of 24 June 2022â [Language: Bahasa Indonesia]     http://web.archive.org/web/20220702083424/https://covid19.go.id/artikel/2022/07/02/realisasi-anggaran-penanganan-covid-19-dan-pemulihan-ekonomi-nasional-pc-pen-24-juni-2022     âAdditionally, for the Community Protection sector: IDR 58.9 trillion (38.1%) [has been allocated], which is used for various programs such as the Family Hope Program (PKH), Basic Food Cards, Pre-Employment Cards, Village Cash Direct Assistance (BLT), Cooking Oil BLT , and BT-PKLWN (Cash Assistance for Street Vendors, Stalls and Fishermen).â     2.	Earlier Indonesian Govt Cabinet press release on 10 May 2022, showing policy has been ongoing prior to 24 June 2022 and policy coverage: [English]  http://web.archive.org/web/20220702084909/https://setkab.go.id/en/pen-budget-realization-reaches-rp70-37-trillion-as-of-april-28-2022/     â[Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs] Airlangga continued, PEN Realization for the Social Protection Program reached Rp49.27 trillion or 31.8 percent of the total ceiling of Rp154.76 trillion.     The realization consists of the Family Hope Program (PKH) amounting to Rp14.15 trillion for 10 million beneficiary families, the Staple Food Card Program amounting to Rp18.8 trillion for 18.8 million beneficiary families, Direct Cash Assistance (BLT) for Cooking Oil amounting to Rp5.8 trillion for 19.3 million beneficiary families, Village Fund Direct Cash Assistance amounting to Rp7.47 trillion for 6.12 million beneficiary families, Cash Assistance for Street Vendors, Vendors, Fishermen (BT-PKLWN) amounting to Rp1.7 trillion and Pre-Employment Card Program amounting to Rp1.4 trillion.]â.     Other evidence of ongoing disbursement:    1.	27 June 2022: Disbursement of Direct Cash Assistance (BLT) Village Fund: [Bahasa]  http://web.archive.org/web/20220702102107/https://kupang.antaranews.com/berita/89861/164-kk-desa-pagomogo-nagekeo-terima-blt-dana-desa

Bantuan Subsidi Upah (BSU), wage subsidy programme, available to Indonesian workers affected by the Covid-19 - main form of government financial assistance. Note about difference from previous coding: Review may be needed; evidence of measures being in place earlier.    Coded 2 for 22â27 June 2022 because of existence of more than one debt/contract relief measure during this period:    A) Reduced taxes (VAT) on items like purchase of houses and cars.  B) Electricity/energy subsidies for households     Additional note: Subsequent updates should monitor for whether these measures are renewed, as sources suggest some will expire in the following months.     A) Reduced VAT policy     1.	Bloomberg (Reported on 19 June 2022) [English] âCovid Stimulus Running Out Threatens Indonesiaâs Growth Target.â     https://archive.ph/lNHAL      âThe exemption of luxury tax payment on new cars priced 200 million rupiah or lower will endâ¦.Also due to expire in September are the 50% VAT discount on purchases of homes valued less than 2 billion rupiah, and the 25% concession on those worth between 2 billion to 5 billion rupiah.â    2.	The Business Times: Details of original policy announcement  (Reported on 16 January 2022) [English]    https://archive.ph/LVb3J     âIndonesia will introduce new tax breaks on property and car sales this year in a bid to accelerate its economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic as authorities prepare for the spread of the Omicron variant, top officials said on Sunday (16 January 2022).â     B) Electricity subsidies    Electricity subsidies remain in place for many lower-income households, but scope is reduced: subsidies removed from households that the government deems to be higher-income, effective from 1 July 2022. No coding change for period of 22â27 June 2022. Reason is that manual contact tracing is still being utilised, but evidence that a significant number of positive cases are not discovered that way.     Note regional variation: COVID-19 cases disproportionately concentrated in the city of Jakarta, as well as other parts of the island of Java, whereas other provinces of Indonesia with much lower case counts able to contact trace quite comprehensively (such as the Riau Islands). Nonetheless, coding unchanged to reflect overall national situation.    1. No policy change for period 22â27 June 2022. Some concern from Indonesian Doctors Association about whether mask rules should be tightened in response to rising cases. However, the relaxed rule (people being allowed take off masks outdoors, unless at a crowded outdoor event/where social distancing is not possible), enacted since 18 May 2022, remains in place.     Previous policy required masking in all public places indoors and outdoors, until relaxation on 18 May 2022 (see policy note on that date for further details).    1.	Kompas.com (22 June 2022) [Bahasa Indonesia]: https://web.archive.org/web/20220627210616/https://health.kompas.com/read/2022/06/22/070000468/ikatan-dokter-indonesia-tegaskan-masih-perlu-pakai-masker?page=all     2.	The Star (25 June 2022) [English] :  https://web.archive.org/web/20220627205724/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2022/06/25/reimpose-stricter-curbs-govt-urged     âThe Indonesian Doctors Association (IDI) has called on the government to review its eased mask-wearing mandate to curb the spread of the virusâ¦Considering the current circumstances, we advise the public to mask up both indoors and outdoors,â Erlina Burhan, a member of IDIâs central board, said on Tuesday as quoted by kompas.com.â     3.	The Straits Times (27 June 2022) [English]: https://web.archive.org/web/20220627201841/https:/www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/omicron-subvariant-wave-may-peak-in-indonesia-in-second-to-third-week-of-july     â"We will maintain the existing health protocols standard, accelerate booster vaccines, conduct our third sero-surveillance in late June-early July," [Health Minister] Budi said on Sunday (June 26). Indonesia on May 18 lifted its mask mandate for outdoor activitiesâ¦Masks must still be worn indoors, on public transportation, and in crowded outdoor spaces by all.â

No changes in policy yet. Government has urged public to start wearing masks outdoor as well since the start of July in response to the new Omicron BA.4 and BA.5 waves, but no new mandatory mask policies have been reinstated. Thus, the law previously enacted on 18 May 2022 is being coded for. On June 10, 2022, restrictions on foreign tourism has been lifted for all countries. For the time being however, all tourists must come with an authorized tour guide or tour company.  For 98 countries deemed as lowest risk, travellers are exempt for additional entry restrictions including screening and quarantine periods even if travellers are unvaccinated.  For 99 countries at the next lowest risk level, travellers are exempt from screening and quarantine period provided they have received 3 doses of the COVID-19 vaccine.  Lastly, there are 4 countries in the highest risk group, these travellers are subjected to mandatory PCR testing and quarantine period on entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220611183656/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220601/k10013652011000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220612032923/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220610/k10013665671000.html

Note about difference from previous coding: Uncertain about basis for 0 in previous update on 6 Jun 2022, compared to previous coding of 1G that had been allocated prior.     1G coding explanation: Schools at all levels seem to be open in Cambodia, but have not found evidence/any announcements from the authorities that all health protocols (such as partial closure if positive case found, social distancing, reduced class sizes, enhanced hygiene and screening) have actually been completely withdrawn. Mask-wearing also seems to continue to be required.     Additionally, no COVID-19 cases were reported in Cambodia during this period, which could explain seeming lack of news about school-based restrictions; does not necessarily mean health protocols have been removed.     1. Most recent school-specific health protocol found reported in English (19 February 2022):     http://web.archive.org/web/20220705131924/https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/schools-allowed-shut-if-covid-cases-found-minister     Education Minister states schools should: facilitate social distancing, promote hygiene, record studentsâ vaccination status including booster shots* and that schools can ask for a vaccination team to be sent to vaccinate students). Schools can close if a positive case is found.     *Not coded as vaccine-differentiated as have not found evidence that lack of vaccination actually results in exclusion from school at present.     2. Continued emphasis on hygiene:     -	24 June 2022: https://archive.ph/PlP0x     3. Evidence of schools being open/activities being resumed (note: many of the articles also show students wearing masks)    -	20 June 2022: Academic competition involving multiple schools     http://web.archive.org/web/20220705133458/https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/kingdoms-top-students-three-subjects-chosen     -	23 June 2022: Extra-curricular activities     http://web.archive.org/web/20220705132634/https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/volunteer-scheme-foster-virtuous-humanitarian-spirit     -	University exams and other activities (University of Cambodia): https://archive.ph/VumUD     4. Additional note: Cambodian authorities cite concern about learning loss impact on primary school students, mention strategies to address it now that in-person classes have resumed.    24 June 2022: https://archive.ph/7uwBd

No coding change from 1G (schools are open, but no evidence that authorities have totally rescinded all health protocols such as safe-distancing and enhanced hygiene).     However, policy note to record authoritiesâ response to fresh COVID-19 outbreak detected in Cambodia on 28 June 2022 after weeks of reporting no new cases.      Cambodian authorities have urged caution, but have not mentioned partial or total school closures as part of the health measures to be stepped up (emphasis on widening testing, booster shots and encouraging people to practise masking, social distancing and hand washing).    Govt strategy seems to not be school closures but preventive measures and vaccination.     A. 	Measures implemented directly referencing schools:    1.	https://archive.ph/uM8Gg     âIn the wake of Covid-19 cases reemerging and the threat of the more serious Omicron variants, the Health Ministry has set up vaccination venues in schools nationwide to push booster dose vaccinations...There is the threat of Omicron variants BA.2, BA.4 and BA.5 circulating among us and scientists have warned that basic doses can no longer protect against the new Omicrom subvariants,â [Ministry of Health official Dr Or] Vandine added.    She said that in view of this, the authorities are creating vaccination venues in all schools for students nationwide to be inoculated with booster shots, whether the third, fourth, or fifth doses.    âTeachers and school staff can receive their shots too,â Vandine said. âWith this measure, the vaccination rate among students will be high and they will have strong immunity.â    B.	Other statements by authorities in response to new outbreak; no mention of school closures but emphasis on hygiene and social distancing in addition to vaccination and testing.      1.	28 June 2022: âCovid-19 cases back in Cambodia, PM affirms.â Emphasis on urging people to take booster shots and â3 Dos and 3 Donâts.â*    https://archive.ph/1FbWB       *Note: â3 Dos and 3 Donâtsâ Refers to wearing a mask, social distancing and washing hands / Avoiding confined spaces, crowds and physical contact:     https://archive.ph/QNPsP#selection-2333.2-2333.288      2.	30 June 2022: âCovid-19 alert at entry points again after cases re-emerge.â Mention of expansion of increased border screening, PCR testing in response to fresh outbreaks.    https://archive.ph/hrAUD      3.	4 July 2022: âGovernment remains vigilant against COVID-19.â Emphasis again on vaccines/booster shots.     https://archive.ph/yR614

No coding change. No evidence found of total or partial closures of economic sectors / workplaces during this period.     Based on available evidence, economic sectors such as tourism and the manufacturing industry (particularly garment/textile), which had been severely affected by closures earlier in the pandemic, seem to be fully open and operating.    Have not found evidence of policies requiring capacity proof of vaccination for entering workplaces; possibly not an issue from the authoritiesâ perspective due to Cambodiaâs high vaccination rate.    1.	21 June 2022: http://web.archive.org/web/20220704153615/https://www.phnompenhpost.com/lifestyle/new-name-cultural-village-reopens-visitors-hit-siem-reap     âThe Ministry of Tourism on June 20, 2022 revealed that 364,636 tourists domestic tourists travelled the country â with Siem Reap welcoming a total of 48,867 visitors â on the weekend of June 18-19, 2022, an increase of 11 .45 per cent on last weekend.â  2.	28 June 2022: The Khmer Times âCambodia records more than 310,000 tourists.â https://archive.ph/52C2n     âMinister Khon said that from June 25 to June 26, the country recorded a total of 318,863 tourists, including 298,940 nationals and 19,923 foreigners.â    3.	Garda, Cambodia country report: https://archive.ph/u3fOI#selection-1869.0-1875.109 (archived 5 July 2022)    â Cambodia has practically removed all coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)-related restrictions following a sharp decline in cases and a high level of vaccination. By mid-June [2022], 85% out of Cambodiaâs 16 million population have been fully vaccinated, while the number of recorded daily cases dropped to 0â¦In March, the government abolished the requirement for fully vaccinated foreign visitors to take COVID-19 tests. The measure should aid the recovery of the tourism sector, a major foreign-exchange earnerâ¦The economic recovery is projected to gather steam in 2022 with support from robust manufacturing activities.â     4.	Xinhua News: âVaccines, FTAs help boost Cambodia's economic recovery: World Bankâ (1 July 2022 report)    http://web.archive.org/web/20220705154115/https://english.news.cn/20220701/8dcc5bbef9e44995a6cba6b98b8d80ec/c.html     âCambodia's total exports rose 34.5 percent year-on-year during the January-May period this year, and traditional growth drivers, especially garments, travel goods and footwear products, continued to expandâ¦Buoyed by its high vaccination coverage, Cambodia has resumed all socio-economic activities and reopened its borders to fully vaccinated travelers without quarantine since November last yearâ

No coding change from 2 (unvaccinated) / 1 (vaccinated) for entire period of 20 Juneâ29 June 2022.     -	Unvaccinated arrivals: Compulsory 7-day quarantine. Not possible to test out of quarantine early. COVID-19 test** administered at the start and end of quarantine for travellers arriving over land borders, but only at the end for those arriving by air.     -	Vaccinated travellers: Must show proof of vaccination. After that need not quarantine or take ART or PCR test.    **Note: Should not affect coding, but some ambiguity regarding the type of test being used. UK Foreign Advice says PCR, Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Cambodian Embassy and Khmer Times newspaper report say ART/rapid test. Possibly explanation is that ART used as a gateway for PCR test (i.e if the ART tests positive) to confirm an infection, as the Cambodian health authorities always mention a positive PCR test when recording cases. See source no. 5 below, where Cambodian health authorities describe this.     Sources:     1. UK Foreign Travel Advisory for Cambodia [archived 30 June 2022]:     http://web.archive.org/web/20220630115417/https:/www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cambodia/entry-requirements      2. Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Cambodia Travel advice [archived 30 June 2022]:    https://archive.ph/rsSb7#selection-1475.0-1563.58     3. Cambodian Embassy, Singapore [archived 4 July 2022]. Note that while original post says 21 November 2021, it has been updated with the latest travel requirements (as seen from the mentioned of the reduced quarantine duration to 7 days that became effective on 22 April 2022 and the removal of PCR tests for vaccinated travellers, which occurred on 17 March 2022).     http://web.archive.org/web/20220704072946/https://www.camemb-sg.com/post/safetravelstocambodia    4. Khmer Times: Description of testing protocol for international arrivals using ART/rapid tests: https://archive.ph/ZGKGG#selection-2201.0-2205.197     5. Khmer Times: Description of ART being used as gateway for PCR test at the border: https://archive.ph/hrAUD#selection-2221.0-2221.199

On 30 June 2022, the Cambodian authorities announced heightened screening at ports of entry, in response to fresh COVID-19 outbreak (new cases first detected on 28 June 2022). In particular, even travellers who have proof of vaccination will be given a rapid test *if* they are displaying COVID-19-like symptoms, and then a PCR test if the first test is positive.     -       Nonetheless, for the period of 30 Juneâ4 July 2022, no coding change from 2 (unvaccinated) / 1 (vaccinated), selective testing of vaccinated people at most constitutes a form of screening.     -      Unvaccinated arrivals must undergo a 7 day quarantine; no exceptions. Rapid/ART test is administered at the start and end of quarantine for land arrivals; only at the end for air travellers.     **Note: No effect on existing coding, but some discrepancy in other countriesâ travel advisories about test type used in Cambodia. UK and Irish foreign advisory say PCR, whereas Singapore MFA, French and US travel advice, Cambodian Embassy and Khmer Times newspaper report say ART/rapid test is used. On the balance, seems ART/rapid test is used. Possibly explanation for discrepancy in UK/Ireland advisory is because ART is used as a gateway for PCR test (i.e if the ART tests positive) to confirm an infection, as the Cambodian health authorities always mention a positive PCR test when recording cases. See source no. 1 below; description of ART as gateway to PCR.     Sources:    1.	30 June 2022 â Khmer Times report: âCovid-19 alert at entry points again after cases re-emerge.â     https://archive.ph/hrAUD     âMinistry of Health spokeswoman Or Vandine [said] that health officials are increasing screening at the borders to check for the virus among inbound travellersâ¦Even if travellers are fully vaccinated, if they display symptoms such as coughing, sore throat, flushed face, fever or temperature of 37 (degrees Celsius) or above, they will automatically be given the rapid tests at entry points by health officials on standby there,â she added. If any individual tests positive, the doctor will then conduct a PCR test.â     2. No policy change for the period 20 Juneâ29 June 2022. As previous note on 6 June records, PCR testing has been scaled down by the government in response to the severity of Cambodiaâs outbreak waning. For this period, testing:     a) Available at only a few locations; not physically accessible to all, as all locations are in the city of Phnom Penh, such as the National Institute of Public Health, Institut Pasteur du Cambodge, Intercare Medical Centre and Preah Ket Mealea Hospital.    b) Financially not as accessible; free PCR tests only at the National Institute of Public Health. Fees seem to be charged for others.       Sources:     1. Archived 27 June 2022: US Embassy, Cambodia. See under section on âCOVID-19 Testingâ for listed locations.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220629181610/https://kh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     Source about testing at the Natâl Institute of Public Health and Preah Ket Mealea Hospital (also in Phnom Penh). Additional testing at a fee, for limited categories people who require proof of being COVID-19 free only (hose travelling abroad, or who need to show their employers they have recovered from COVID-19).     2. Reported 13 June 2022:  https://archive.ph/I9Vxl#selection-2191.0-2213.170     âFor all those seeking PCR tests please perform it at the National Institute of Public Health for free, and those found infected must report this to officials in the area like before (during the pandemic).â    âSince Covid-19 became endemic, the Health Ministry suspended free PCR (polymerase chain reaction) tests for the public at government facilities.    The Preah Ket Mealea Hospital is providing this, at a fee, for those requiring certificates showing they are virus free.    These tests, for which a fee is charged, are sought by those who wish to travel abroad or have had Covid-19 and wish to prove to their employers that they have recovered.â

Effective from 30 June 2022, the Ministry of Health announced it had drastically expanded PCR testing again and reinstated free testing nationwide, in response to the ongoing, fresh COVID-19 outbreak that was first detected on 28 June 2022 after several weeks where Cambodia had reported zero cases.    Coding changed to 3 as significant spatial expansion to all public hospitals (testing facilities confined to Phnom Penh in previous update on 20 June 2022) and increased accessibility (free and eligibility criteria is much widerâanyone who suspects they have COVID-19).    1. Khmer Times article [30 June 2022]: "Covid-19 alert at entry points again after cases reemerge".     https://archive.ph/hrAUD     â[Ministry of Health spokeswoman] Dr Or Vandine said the ministry has reintroduced the free RDT and PCR at referral hospitals and health centres nationwide.    Previously, RDT and PCR tests could only be taken at a few locations such as Khmer Soviet Friendship Hospital in Phnom Penh and in front of the Christian church in Stung Meanchey, with long crowded queues causing tempers to flare. The testing at all referral hospitals had been stopped because no cases were being recorded in the Kingdom.â    âFor the convenience of people, all referral hospitals and health centre across the country are conducting RDT or PCR tests to the general public to facilitate anybody who suspects they have Covid-19,â she added.â

No coding change for the period 20â27 June 2022; as Cambodia reported no new or active COVID-19 cases throughout this period, presumably no contact tracing would have to be carried out.    21 June 2022: http://web.archive.org/web/20220704125401/https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/no-new-covid-cases-cambodia-31     24 June 2022: http://web.archive.org/web/20220704125415/https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/no-new-covid-cases-cambodia-34     26 June 2022: http://web.archive.org/web/20220704125424/https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/no-new-covid-cases-cambodia-36     Article on 28 June 2022 about fresh outbreak confirms that prior 52 days had reported 0 new daily COVID-19 cases:     https://archive.ph/1FbWB     Last active patient had also recovered on 7 June 2022 âÂ Xinhua News "Cambodia becomes COVID free":  https://archive.ph/rBErO

No coding change for period 28 Juneâ4 July 2022, however policy note to address developments resulting from new and ongoing COVID-19 outbreak in Cambodia since 28 June 2022. No coding change for the period 20â2 July 2022.    Since the requirement of wearing masks in open outdoor spaces was removed on 26 April 2022, rule is that masks are mandatory only in indoor public spaces. From Facebook Page of Office of Te Beretitenti: Curfew hours no longer in operation for islands affected by Covid-19.    The Government of Kiribati has reduced the COVID-19 Alert Level from 3b to 3c and relaxed the SOP guidelines currently being practiced as part of Kiribatiâs preventive measures for COVID-19.    The New Public Health Order is effective from Friday 17th of June, 2022 and will remain for two weeks as the curfew hours have ceased for all islands that are infected by COVID-19. Furthermore, inter-island travel will still be subject to the availability of quarantine centers on islands that are COVID-19 free.    For internal and international travels, the Government has reduced the number of days spent in quarantine centers for all travelers from seven (7) to three (3) days. All international travel to and from Kiribati will return to normal on the 1st of August, 2022. From Facebook page of Office of Te Beretitenti: announces lifting of quarantine requirement for inbound passengers from abroad from 2nd July.  This also applies to passengers travelling to outer islands that are Covid-19 free.    "The Government of Kiribati has lifted quarantine requirements to all inbound passengers from abroad including passengers travelling to the outer islands, effective from Saturday, 2nd of July 2022.    The Government made the decision based on the Ministry of Health and Medical Services advice that vaccination rate across Kiribati has been increased since the majority of the eligible population have been vaccinated, including the vaccine roll-out for those aged 12-17 years.    Under this new decision, inbound travelers from abroad should be tested with negative result 24 hours before travel and upon arrival in Tarawa, they will be check out from the terminal to their homes. This also applies to passengers travelling from Tarawa or outer islands to islands that are COVID-19 free.    Members of the general public are reminded that despite the relaxation of some of the SOP guidelines, the Government appeals to the general public that all the other requirements in the previous order will remain, such as face mask, use vaccination card for travels and others.    In light of this, the Government appeals to the general public to strictly comply with the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) to assist in safeguarding our children and grandchildren from the spread of COVID-19." From Facebook Page of Office of Te Beretitenti:  Quarantine for international passengers has reduced from 7 to 3 days.  Plan announced that international travel will return to normal on 1st August.    The Government of Kiribati has reduced the COVID-19 Alert Level from 3b to 3c and relaxed the SOP guidelines currently being practiced as part of Kiribatiâs preventive measures for COVID-19.    The New Public Health Order is effective from Friday 17th of June, 2022 and will remain for two weeks as the curfew hours have ceased for all islands that are infected by COVID-19. Furthermore, inter-island travel will still be subject to the availability of quarantine centers on islands that are COVID-19 free.    For internal and international travels, the Government has reduced the number of days spent in quarantine centers for all travelers from seven (7) to three (3) days. All international travel to and from Kiribati will return to normal on the 1st of August, 2022. From Facebook page of Office of Te Beretitenti: announces lifting of quarantine requirement for inbound passnengers from abroad from 2nd July    "The Government of Kiribati has lifted quarantine requirements to all inbound passengers from abroad including passengers travelling to the outer islands, effective from Saturday, 2nd of July 2022.    The Government made the decision based on the Ministry of Health and Medical Services advice that vaccination rate across Kiribati has been increased since the majority of the eligible population have been vaccinated, including the vaccine roll-out for those aged 12-17 years.    Under this new decision, inbound travelers from abroad should be tested with negative result 24 hours before travel and upon arrival in Tarawa, they will be check out from the terminal to their homes. This also applies to passengers travelling from Tarawa or outer islands to islands that are COVID-19 free.    Members of the general public are reminded that despite the relaxation of some of the SOP guidelines, the Government appeals to the general public that all the other requirements in the previous order will remain, such as face mask, use vaccination card for travels and others.    In light of this, the Government appeals to the general public to strictly comply with the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) to assist in safeguarding our children and grandchildren from the spread of COVID-19." The visitation restriction of nursing hospitals for unvaccinated people is lifted, thus they can visit nursing hospitals in person. However, visitors are still required to submit a negative Covid-19 test result. https://archive.ph/6hGLy

* No new information found    Officials in Laos have tightened restrictions as of April 1 due to increased COVID-19 activity. Preschools and primary schools have suspended on-site teaching activities for levels 1 to 4. Classes that remain on-site must observe health protocols, such as not sharing meals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625215239/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/04/laos-local-and-central-authorities-tightening-restrictions-as-of-april-1-due-to-increased-covid-19-activity-update-45

Public places and services  As of 9 May 2022, all public places and services have reopened. You should still carry evidence of your vaccination status at all times as some places and services may still require this.    Relaxed measures:  Most businesses and venues outside of areas with community outbreak are authorised to open as long as owners, staff and customers are fully vaccinated.    Businesses are required to have COVID preventative measures in place. These include providing alcohol gel, face masks being worn, 1m physical distancing and checking temperatures.    The embassy recommends you check in advance the status of any establishments and carry your proof of vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625214929/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/laos/coronavirus

As of April 1, Vientiane Province allows weddings and festivals to occur only with advance approval from local officials.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625215239/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/04/laos-local-and-central-authorities-tightening-restrictions-as-of-april-1-due-to-increased-covid-19-activity-update-45

Local officials in some areas may implement stricter curbs, including suspending or requiring organizers of gatherings to obtain approval.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625215428/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/05/laos-authorities-continue-to-enforce-restrictions-as-of-may-2-due-to-covid-19-update-46

Domestic and international flights are operating regularly.  Notifications of sudden and significant reductions in flight availability will be reported via messages sent to those who have enrolled in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program (STEP).  Please enroll with STEP using the link to receive these alerts or you can find them on our alerts page.  Is public transportation operating? Yes    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625215743/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Additionally, local officials in some areas have implemented stricter curbs. Some localities, including Houaphan, Savannakhet, and Vientiane provinces, have suspended entertainment venues like pubs and bars. Vientiane Province allows weddings and festivals to occur only with advance approval from local officials. Luang Namtha Province requires domestic entrants to be fully vaccinated and has enacted a 23:00-05:00 curfew, with exceptions for good transport and emergency vehicles, among others. Similar measures may be in effect in other provinces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625215239/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/04/laos-local-and-central-authorities-tightening-restrictions-as-of-april-1-due-to-increased-covid-19-activity-update-45

Travel restrictions within Laos have been lifted. Authorisation for travel by road, water and air between provinces is no longer required for travellers carrying proof of full vaccination. You should consult with provincial COVID-19 Task Forces for guidance for those who are not fully vaccinated or are too young to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625214929/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/laos/coronavirus

* Policy response in 2021, no changes found.    On June 30, the government approved a budget of 1.5 billion kip to disburse cash allowances for the poorest and provide other subsidies for almost 6,000 low-income earners and informal sector workers who have lost income due to the pandemic and suffered extreme financial hardship.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625220742/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

* Policy response in 2021, no changes found.    New fiscal measures were introduced by the government, including income tax exemption for both civil servants and employees of private sector with income less than 5 million kip per month for three months; profit tax exemption for microenterprises with annual income between 50â400 million kip for three months; duty fee exemption for imports of goods to be used towards the outbreak; and deferral of road tax payments from March 31 to June 30.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220625220742/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
Coordinated campaign    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625220540/https://www.covid19.gov.la/index.php

The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE) is the central authority for COVID-19 in Laos (tel: 021-312351.)  In order to be tested for COVID-19, you must qualify under the following testing criteria:    All new entrees to Laos;  People who have symptoms of COVID-19;  People with severe acute respiratory infection;  People who will travel abroad (and are approved by the Government of Laos COVID-19 Task Force)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625215743/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

*Contact tracing policy in 2021, no changes found    According to a notice issued 26 June, the Lao National Taskforce for Covid-19 Prevention and Control has instructed all residents of Laos to install the app on their smartphone after facing difficulty tracing people suspected of being infected with Covid-19.    Residents who do not have a smartphone will be required to write down their phone number when visiting shops, businesses, and restaurants.    Authorities say the information will be kept strictly confidential and will only remain in the system for a period of 30 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625221021/https://laotiantimes.com/2021/07/05/laos-covid-taskforce-unveils-new-contact-tracing-qr-code/

People must wear facemasks and observe social distancing rules when in public, though the enforcement level varies across the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625221226/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/05/laos-authorities-ease-international-travel-restrictions-as-of-may-9-update-47

The Laos national vaccination programme started in November 2020 using the AstraZeneca, Sinopharm, Sinovac, Pfizer-BioNTech and Janssen (Johnson and Johnson) vaccines and as of November 2021 has begun offering booster shots to sections of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625214929/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/laos/coronavirus
No policies found for the protection of the elderly.    * notes of previous coders only shows elderly people have priority when it comes to vaccinations

China's Macao Special Administrative Region (SAR) on 19th June reported 12 locally transmitted COVID-19 cases, according to the Novel Coronavirus Response and Coordination Center of Macao. Authorities have advised residents to remain at home. All businesses must suspend operations, though casinos and supermarkets may remain open. Dine-in services are banned. Public venues, including schools, parks, museums, and sports facilities must close. Public sectors, except for emergency and essential services, will also suspend operations through June 21.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220621144105/https://www.cnbc.com/2022/06/20/macao-shuts-businesses-restaurants-due-to-covid-but-casinos-stay-open.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220621144116/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/06/china-macau-officials-imposing-tighter-domestic-covid-19-curbs-as-of-june-20-update-72  https://web.archive.org/web/20220621144135/http://english.news.cn/20220619/feac3677f17d4d16aa171e4e17d67956/c.html

Officials in Macau are imposing tighter domestic curbs as of June 20 due to COVID-19 activity. Mass testing of residents is underway through the afternoon of June 21. Authorities have advised residents to remain at home. All businesses must suspend operations, though casinos and supermarkets may remain open. Dine-in services are banned. Public venues, including schools, parks, museums, and sports facilities must close.    Buildings where two or more positive cases have been detected are classified as lockdown zones (red-coded zones). The control measure of red health code is imposed, with lockdown management implemented for at least five days. People in the related zones are required to undergo nucleic acid tests on Days 1 and 5, and carry out rapid antigen test on Days 2, 3 and 4. If there is no sign of ongoing transmission within the zone during the period, lockdown measures will be lifted on Day 5 when the NAT results become available; as such, the health code of the individuals inside will be converted to yellow code on Days 6 and 7, and they must conduct a nuclear acid test on Day 7. During the period of lockdown management, people are only allowed to enter and not allowed to go out of the red-coded zones, except for the working staff. Their activities are required to be kept to a minimum, such as picking up supplies at the designated location only. Comprehensive restriction and closed-off management are implemented. On-site isolation and medical observation or transfer to an appropriate location to receive medical observation of centralised management will be carried out according to the actual situation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220701121019/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/06/china-macau-officials-imposing-tighter-domestic-covid-19-curbs-as-of-june-20-update-72  https://www.gcs.gov.mo/detail/en/N22FWwNv6Q?1  (the second link can not be archived)
