These exceptional venues must ensure that all staff, visitors, and performers are fully vaccinated or hold a negative nucleic acid COVID-19 test result valid for 48 hours. Thermal scanners are in place at all entry points into Macau and many businesses, including casinos.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220711162057/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/06/china-macau-officials-imposing-tighter-domestic-covid-19-curbs-as-of-june-20-update-72

Travellers arriving in Macao, who are not residents of Macao, Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China, will be denied entry. There are a small number of exemptions for certain categories of traveller, including non-resident workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220701142147/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/macao/entry-requirements

The Macao government has announced that all travellers arriving in Macao, who are not residents of Macao, Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China, will be denied entry. Residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China who have travelled overseas in the 21 days prior to their arrival will also be denied entry.  Residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan or Mainland China, who have visited Hong Kong 21 days prior to arriving in Macao, must hold a certificate of a negative result for COVID-19 nucleic acid test performed within the past 24 hours and will need to go to a designated places for a 14-day medical observation on arrival in Macao. Residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan or Mainland China, who have visited Taiwan 14 days prior to arriving in Macao, must hold a certificate of a negative result for COVID-19 nucleic acid test issued within the past 7 days and will need to go to a designated places for a 14-day medical observation.  Residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan or Mainland China, who have visited Mainland China 14 days prior to arriving in Macao, must hold a certificate of a negative result or a certificate of specimen collection for COVID-19 nucleic acid test issued within the past 7 days. The Macao Special Administrative Region Government has placed further restrictions on arrivals from specific locations within Mainland China.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220711164524/https://travelbans.org/en/asia/macau

Land rental: Exemption of land rental under MOP$100.00.  Property tax: Standard deduction of MOP$3,500.00 on property tax. If the taxpayer is two or more natural persons (individuals), its property tax can be similarly deducted the aforementioned amount if and only if one of them is permanent resident of Macao SAR. If the taxpayer is a legal person, individual commercial entrepreneur or non-resident of Macao SAR, it is not eligible for such deduction.     Salaries tax: 30% exemption on salaries tax and the exemption allowance for its assessment in 2022 is MOP$144,000.00. In case of the following situation: employer should withhold tax from causal worker whose daily salary is over MOP$640.00 or employee whose monthly salary is over MOP$16,000.00. Please refer to the Simulation Calculation disposal in website of FSB. In addition, exemption allowance for part-time and employee who are aged 65 or above or with permanent disability level of or above 60%, is adjusted to MOP$198,000.00.    https://archive.ph/Ulgt3

In response to the COVID-19 outbreak in Macao since 18 June, the Novel Coronavirus Response and Coordination Centre has decided to require all people in Macao to conduct rapid antigen tests (RATs) for COVID-19 for two consecutive days starting from 1 July to 2 July.  If the test result is declared as positive, the health code will be converted to a âred codeâ. If the test result is declared as positive by mistake, one is requested to re-declare it as soon as possible by re-selecting the result as ânegativeâ and submitting the correct result photo, the health code will not be affected then.    https://www.gcs.gov.mo/detail/en/U22FdcEhQw?1  (the link cannot be archived)

The requirement to produce the Macao Health Code for entry into public places will help to reduce the risk of infection of people with suspected symptoms of novel coronavirus pneumonia in public places. Some domestic flights have resumed in Burma. Contact domestic airlines for details about COVID-19 related travel procedures.  U.S. citizens traveling or residing anywhere in Burma should ensure they have the latest information on COVID-19 prevention measures in the locations they plan to visit, or currently reside in. Arrivals to Myanmar must be fully vaccinated, and must present proof they have received their second vaccine dose at least 14 days prior to arrival. Alternatively, arrivals can present proof they have recovered from COVID-19.  Arrivals must also provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 PCR test result. The test should be issued no more than 72 hours prior to the date of departure from the origin airport.     Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? â NO if RDT test is COVID-19 negative.  If RDT test is COVID-19 positive, the traveler will be isolated, transferred and treated in a designated hospital or treatment center or hotel.  https://archive.ph/51kEG  https://archive.ph/LSgT3

Regular updates on covid-19, given through the MySejahtera app and local news media.

The government has coordinated a public campaign such as a building website for COVID-19. Also, regular updates on covid-19 are given through the MySejahtera app and local news media.    https://archive.ph/IetRR  https://archive.ph/zIWvA
Anyone can get tested as a precautionary measure, even if they're asymptomatic, if needed.  Link: https://archive.ph/0KBH2
Self-administered Testing kits are now also available to be ordered from the government website.  PCR and antigen tests are generally available.    https://archive.ph/uqGAG
Contact tracing is done through the MySejahtera app. Not have the app installed on your phone means being denied entry to any public space.

Starting May 1, it is no longer compulsory for MySejahtera check-in when entering public places or premises.  Health Minister Khairy Jamaluddin said people are encouraged to activate the MySJ Trace function in their MySejahtera app for the purpose of contact tracing.  People with "high risk" status on the MySejahtera and those placed under House Surveillance Order (HSO), he said, are not allowed to enter the premises.  "The management of the premises can check the risk status of the people (as displayed in the MySejahtera app) before allowing them to enter the premises," he told a press conference here today.  Khairy said the MySejahtera application was still important for the purpose of reporting the result of Covid-19 self test and the enforcement of the HSO, as well as helping the ministry to manage the Covid-19 transmission.    https://archive.ph/e0b5l  https://archive.ph/zIWvA
Mask wearing is still mandatory indoors, although not anymore outdoors. This applied to everyone, including the vaccinated population.  Link: https://archive.ph/azLGg

Wearing a face mask is mandatory indoors, including on public transport and e-hailing rides. Optional when outdoors but encouraged in crowded places. High-risk individuals are also encouraged to wear a mask.    https://archive.ph/D14lZ

Now, all age groups can get vaccinated, including children. Full vaccination is compulsory to access public spaces and everyone needs to get vaccinated. Vaccines are government funded and are available on an appointment booking system via the MySejahtera app. This applies to both citizens and non-citizens, with priority given to those above the age of 60.  Link: https://archive.ph/jVXjp

All vaccines are funded by the government.    https://archive.ph/uqGAG

Ministry of Health:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220704112333/https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus  Unite Against Covid-19:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220704112344/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-orange/

Vaccination is required for entry into New Zealand unless you:  - are a New Zealand citizen  - have a New Zealand residence class visa  - are an Australian citizen living in New Zealand  - are a child aged 16 years and under  - cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons â you will need electronic or paper evidence from a health practitioner  - are a refugee arriving in New Zealand for the first time  - are a citizen of Afghanistan and you are being evacuated  - are arriving from Antarctica  - have been granted a visa under the 2022 Special Ukraine Visa Policy; or if you are or were ordinarily resident in Ukraine at any point on or after 1 January 2022.    Travellers do not need proof of a negative pre-departure test to enter New Zealand from 21 June 2022. Most people entering New Zealand must take 2 rapid antigen tests (RAT) after they arrive â the first on Day 0/1 and the second on Day 5/6.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220704113351/https://covid19.govt.nz/international-travel/travel-to-new-zealand/preparing-to-travel-to-new-zealand/#exempt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220704113401/https://covid19.govt.nz/international-travel/travel-to-new-zealand/vaccination-requirements-for-travel-to-new-zealand/

Estacion said health authorities in the towns and cities are relentlessly undertaking contact tracing to prevent Covid-19 transmission, especially with the new Omicron sub-variants that could rapidly spread compared to the older variants.  Philippine News Agency: https://web.archive.org/web/20220624084911/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1177162    How is contact tracing done:  Upon identification of a suspect, probable, or confirmed case, the designated Safety and Health Offices shall initiate contact tracing within the office/floor/building to identify 70% of all possible close contacts within 24 hours and 100% within 48 hours. Contact tracing shall also commence for contacts of suspect cases upon identification while waiting for specimen collection for SARS- CoV-2 diagnostic testing or RT-PCR results. Identification of second and third - generation close contacts is highly encouraged.  Department of Health: https://web.archive.org/web/20220531151026/https://doh.gov.ph/node/33556

Identification of second and third - generation close contacts is highly encouraged.  Department of Health: https://web.archive.org/web/20220711130005/https://doh.gov.ph/node/33556

The restrictions of movement for unvaccinated individuals in the National Capital Region (NCR) will be lifted once alert level classification is lowered to Alert Level 2, acting Presidential spokesperson, Cabinet Secretary Karlo Nograles, said Wednesday.    "You have to go back to the ordinances. I believe the ordinances really state that this no vax, no ride or the limitations or the restrictions based on the ordinances only for Alert Level 3 or higher. So, meaning to say, when you deescalate, then obviously the ordinance can longer be implemented," Nograles said in a television interview.    As there are no longer any regions at Alert Level 3 or higher, the mandatory vaccination is removed from coding.     Philippine News Agency: https://archive.ph/LJYBc  US Embassy: https://web.archive.org/web/20220625154927/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-and-travel-information/

All foreign nationals traveling to Papua New Guinea must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 using an approved vaccine (currently Oxford-AstraZenica; Pfizer-BioNTech; Moderna; Johnson & Johnson; Sinopharm-BBIBP; and CoronaVac Sinovac) unless they are under age 18 or a citizen or permanent resident of Papua New Guinea.  COVID-19 rapid test is administered upon arrival for all travelers arriving from any country other than Australia. If negative, the traveler does not have to quarantine. If positive, a PCR test will be performed to confirm the result. If the PCR test is also positive, the traveler must immediately quarantine for 7 days at the travelerâs expense.     https://archive.ph/maUJh

No coding changes to the period of 18 June - 02 July 2022.    Quote (1):  "In line with the further easing of community measures, the following adjustments will be implemented in the Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) from 26 Apr 2022:    No group size and safe distancing requirements;  Mask-wearing will be required indoors as a default. Unmasking indoors is only allowed for select activities (e.g. consumption of food and beverages, sports, live performances);  In line with national posture, Vaccination Differentiated Safe Management Measures (VDS) will only apply to events with more than 500 participants, and dining in at F&B establishments on IHL campuses; and  TraceTogether-only SafeEntry check-ins in IHLs are no longer required.  Screening    Students and staff who are unwell with flu-like symptoms are required to stay away from campus. They should seek medical attention immediately and be tested for COVID-19. Unwell individuals should remain at home until they test negative for COVID-19.  Hygiene    Frequent cleaning of high-touch surfaces and disinfection of the premises.  Mask Wearing    All students, staff, vendors and visitors are required to wear masks whenever they are indoors. Unmasking indoors is only allowed for select activities (e.g. consumption of food and beverages, sports, live performances).  The use of face shields instead of masks is allowed for the following groups or in the following settings:  Persons who have health conditions that may result in breathing or medical difficulties when a mask is worn for a prolonged period of time; and  Persons who are speaking to a group in a classroom or lecture-style setting, where they largely remain at the spot where they are speaking, and are able to maintain a safe distance from other persons. This would include teachers and lecturers in schools and IHLs respectively, when they are in their classrooms and lecture halls."    Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702185148/https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection

No coding changes to the period of 18 June - 02 July 2022.    Vaccine-differentiated measures have now been removed for most settings, including workplaces. However, some COVID-19 safety measurements remain in place.  --------  Quote (1):  "3. Workplace Requirements    All employees may now return to the workplace.  *In indoor settings, employees may also remove their masks at the workplace: (i) when they are not interacting physically with others and (ii) when they are not in customer-facing areas. "    Other Adjustments to Community Measures    Stepping down on the use of TraceTogether (TT) and SafeEntry (SE)  COVID-19 cases no longer need to upload their TT data or submit their TT token.   SafeEntry check-ins will be removed from malls, supermarkets, hawker centres, coffee shops, etc. Random spot-checks will continue to be conducted to ensure that only fully vaccinated persons are dining in at F&B establishments.  Check-in will only be required at events with more than 500 participants at any one time, and certain nightlife establishments, for verification of vaccination status.     [Updated] SMMs for nightlife establishments  From 14 June 2022, the following will apply to nightlife establishments with dancing among patrons:    No capacity limits  Patrons need not obtain a negative Antigen Rapid Test (ART) result to enter the venue  Vaccinated-Differentiated SMMs (VDS) will continue to apply, and operators will still be required to conduct VDS checks to ensure that only fully vaccinated persons enter these settings  Random checks may be conducted by enforcement officers to ensure that operators comply with the requirement for VDS checks.    Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702185727/https://www.gov.sg/article/further-easing-of-community-measures  ________________________________    Quote (2):  "WORKPLACES  â¢ All employees may return to the workplace.  â¢ Unmasking allowed at workplace if one is not interacting physically with others and when not in customer-facing areas.   â¢ Workforce Vaccination Measures lifted. See MOMâs advisory."    Link (2): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702185521/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19-phase-advisory

If >500 attendees, all must be fully vaccinated.  â¢ Performers or speakers may be unmasked, including for singing or playing of wind instruments at live performances.    CONGREGATIONAL & WORSHIP SERVICES  â¢ No capacity limit. If >500 attendees, all must be fully vaccinated.  â¢ Performers or speakers may be unmasked, including for singing or playing of wind instruments at live performances.  â¢ Congregational singing and chanting is allowed, provided attendees are mask-on in line with indoor masking requirement.    MARRIAGE SOLEMNISATIONS  â¢ No capacity limit. If >500 attendees, all must be fully vaccinated.  â¢ Home solemnisations: No limit on the number of non-resident visitors to the home.    WEDDING RECEPTIONS  â¢ No capacity limit. If >500 attendees, all must be fully vaccinated.    Link (2): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702185521/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19-phase-advisory

Link (1): http://archive.today/2022.06.17-060745/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19-phase-advisory  Link (2): http://archive.today/2022.06.17-055925/https://www.gov.sg/article/further-easing-of-community-measures

No coding changes to the period of 18 June - 02 July 2022.    Quote (1):  "1. Entry Criteria and Travel Checklists  Under Singaporeâs Vaccinated Travel Framework, all travellers including Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents arriving from all countries/regions can enter Singapore without quarantine, testing or entry approvals if they meet the following requirements:    Be a child born in or after 2010 (i.e. aged 12 and below by year of birth) â children who meet this age criteria can enter regardless of COVID-19 vaccination status    Be fully vaccinated with WHO EUL vaccines if born in or before 2009 (i.e. aged 13 and above by year of birth) â âFully vaccinatedâ means at least one dose of CanSinoBIO/Convidecia or Janssen/J&J, or at least 2 doses of AstraZeneca, Covaxin, Moderna/Spikevax, Covishield, Novavax/Covovax/Nuvaxovid, Pfizer/BioNTech/COMIRNATY, Sinovac or Sinopharm. Mixed doses and boosters using these WHO EUL vaccines, and vaccination with recovery are also acceptable. For full definition, see Accepted COVID-19 Vaccinations for Entry to Singapore.    Be vaccinated against Yellow Fever if you have visited Yellow Fever high risk countries/regions in Africa and Latin America - a valid Yellow Fever vaccination certificate is required.  If you meet the requirements above, click the green button below for a detailed step-by-step travel checklist that explains the administrative requirements (e.g. proof of vaccination, SG Arrival Card, etc) for entry.    Travellers born in or before 2009 (i.e. age 13 and above by year of birth) who do not meet the vaccination requirements above are considered non-fully vaccinated travellers and will be subject to entry approvals, tests and quarantine. This includes travellers who:    Are medically exempted from COVID-19 vaccination  Took non-WHO EUL vaccines and/or did not complete the full dosage of WHO EUL COVID-19 vaccines  Recovered from COVID-19 but did not complete the minimum dosage of WHO EUL COVID-19 vaccines  Generally, non-fully vaccinated long term pass holders and short-term visitors are not allowed to enter Singapore unless in exceptional circumstances. Non-fully vaccinated travellers should click the orange button below for a detailed checklist of travel requirements.    Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702191738/https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/arriving/overview

No coding changes to the period of 18 June - 02 July 2022.    Additional Cash payouts in the form of vouchers that can be used at select locations in-country were made available on 11 May 2022. Additional rounds will ensure over the next 2 years; as well as rebates and relief for items such as utility bills. This scheme has bene brought forward as global prices for commodities continue to rise as a consequence of continued COVID-19 induced supply disruptions as well as the war in Ukraine. Financial assistance given by the government is tailored according to the overall socioeconomic status of the household; with lower income households receiving more assistance.  -------    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - All Singaporean households can now collect $100 worth of Community Development Council (CDC) vouchers to spend at more than 16,000 participating heartland merchants and hawkers. In addition, $200 more in vouchers will be disbursed in early 2023, and another $200 in 2024, with major supermarkets roped in for the next two years. The latest vouchers will benefit up to 1.22 million Singaporean households. They can be collected digitally from Wednesday (May 11), and can be used until Dec 31 together with the vouchers released last year."    "However, he decided to bring it forward as many Singaporeans are concerned about their daily expenses and the impact of rising prices due to the ongoing war in Ukraine. He noted that prices have been increasing worldwide both because of the Ukraine war and the continued shipping and supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic. "Even countries that are oil and gas exporters are facing higher prices, let alone a small and open economy like Singapore that imports almost everything we consume," he said. "So we do have to brace ourselves for higher prices for some time. But rest assured that the Government will continue to do our utmost to help cushion the impact for Singaporeans, especially for our lower- and middle-income families. "In particular, we will continue to monitor the global situation, and will not hesitate to take further action to help households and businesses if the situation worsens."    "Mr Wong noted that the Government is also providing other forms of assistance. The first tranche of service and conservancy charges (S&CC) and GST Voucher (GSTV) U-Save utilities rebates was disbursed last month. Another three rounds will be disbursed in July, October and next January. The payouts are part of the enhanced permanent GSTV scheme and Household Support Package announced at Budget 2022 to defray GST and other living expenses. This means that those living in four-room HDB flats will receive rebates worth about four months of their utility bills and 2Â½ months of their S&CC for the whole of financial year 2022, said Mr Wong."    Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702192004/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/each-sporean-household-to-get-100-cdc-vouchers-from-today    ------------------    Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - About 950,000 households living in Housing Board flats will receive their quarterly Goods and Services Tax (GST) Voucher U-Save rebates in April, the first payout of the fiscal year. The total rebates each eligible household will receive in FY2022 range from $440 to $760, depending on the HDB flat type. They will be given in four tranches - in April, July and October this year, and January 2023. The payments are meant to help lower- and middle-income Singaporeans offset their GST and utility bills. The Government has been giving out GST Vouchers in three components - cash, MediSave and U-Save for utilities - since 2012. From FY2022, the service and conservancy charges (S&CC) rebate will be a component of the scheme. For this financial year, households will receive double the U-Save payments, which come in the form of rebates in utility bills. For those residing in one- and two-room flats, the rebate amounts to about eight to 10 months of utility bills. For those living in three- and four-room flats, the rebate works out to about four to six months of utility bills, said MOF. The payouts, totalling $720 million, were announced at Budget 2022 in February and are part of the enhanced permanent GST Voucher scheme and the Household Support Package. It was also made known that GST will be raised by 1 percentage point a year over the next two years, from 7 per cent to 9 per cent."    Link (2): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702192138/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/housing/950000-hdb-households-to-receive-gst-u-save-rebates-in-april  -----------------    Quote (3):  "SINGAPORE - Households will receive more help through vouchers and rebates to cope with higher prices from rising inflation globally, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong during his Budget speech on Friday (Feb 18). A $560 million Household Support Package will help Singaporean families manage cost of living pressures, by providing support for daily essentials through utilities rebates, top-ups for children's education and vouchers they can use at heartland shops."    Link (3): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702192339/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/budget-2022-households-to-get-more-rebates-100-cdc-voucher  ----------------    Budget announcements earlier in the year included a wide range of aspects to help cushion the impact of Covid-19 on it's citizens and residents. Projected to take place over the next few years.    Link (4): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702192453/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/budget-2022-560-million-household-support-package-2506476  Link (5): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702192602/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/budget-2022-gst-rate-household-business-support-cpf-carbon-tax-2506736  _______________________________      Other resources:  Link [1]: http://archive.today/2022.06.07-060551/https://www.wsg.gov.sg/hiring-incentive.html  Link [2]: http://archive.today/2022.06.07-060753/https://www.pap.org.sg/news/1-6b-care-and-support-package-what-you-can-get/?doing_wp_cron=1654582076.5744750499725341796875  Link [3]: http://archive.today/2022.06.07-060948/https://supportgowhere.life.gov.sg/  Link [4]: http://archive.today/2022.06.07-061138/https://www.gobusiness.gov.sg/supportschemes/immediateschemes  Link [5}: http://archive.today/2022.06.07-061329/https://www.iras.gov.sg/schemes/disbursement-schemes/jobs-support-scheme-(jss)  Link [6]: http://archive.today/2022.06.07-061525/https://www.gov.sg/article/jobsgohere-covid-support  Link [7]: http://archive.today/2022.06.07-061813/https://www.msf.gov.sg/assistance/Pages/covid19relief.aspx  Link [8]: http://archive.today/2022.06.07-061926/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/advisory-on-salary-and-leave

Mask-Wearing  Mask-wearing will continue to be required in indoor settings when people leave their homes, including on public transport, but will remain optional in outdoor settings. No coding changes to the period of 18 June - 02 July 2022.  ________________________________    Boosters, when due, are required for individuals to be considered "fully vaccinated". Optional second booster doses now available for those 60 years and above. There is currently no mandate for a second booster dose in-country. A new addition of an approved non-mRNA vaccine (Novavax/Nuvaxovid) has been added to the national vaccination programme; adults 18 and above are now able to opt for this as a booster dose over the other mRNA options that have been on the programme's list since the start of the campaign. As this has been added to the National Vaccination programme, it will be government funded and no out-of-pocket payment is required for those covered by the programme. There is universal availability in-country, only second boosters are given out in prioritised groups.  -----------------  Groups: Universal availability    Vaccines:    1. Moderna (Government Funded)   2. Pfizer-BioNTech/Comirnaty (Government Funded)   3. Sinovac-Coronavac (Government Funded) [7] - 3 doses required for Full Vax status [8]  4. Sinopharm (Government Funded/Individual cost through the Private sector only ) - SAR    5. AstraZeneca (Individual cost through the Private sector only ) - SAR    6. Novavax/Nuvaxovid (Government funded)    *SAR = Special Access Route  ____________________________________      Quote (1):  "Bookings for Nuvaxovid - the first non-mRNA vaccine recommended as a booster dose by the Expert Committee on Covid-19 Vaccination - were opened to residents aged 18 and above since May 13. Administration of the Novavax vaccine at any of the participating Public Health Preparedness Clinics started on May 18. It is also available at JTVC Bishan, one of five new joint testing and vaccination centres that will open on Tuesday. There is no charge for the vaccination.    Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702194147/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/more-than-1000-people-sign-up-to-take-novavaxs-non-mrna-covid-19-vaccine  ------------------    Quote (2):  14TH FEB 2022  The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has accepted the recommendation of the Expert Committee on COVID-19 Vaccination to include the Nuvaxovid COVID-19 vaccine (Nuvaxovid) by Novavax in the National Vaccination Programme for use in individuals aged 18 years and above, for both COVID-19 primary and booster vaccination. This follows the Health Sciences Authority's (HSA) interim authorisation of the vaccine under the Pandemic Special Access Route.    2.    The first batch of the Nuvaxovid vaccine is expected to arrive in Singapore in the next few months if there are no disruptions to the shipment schedule. We will roll out the Nuvaxovid vaccine for individuals aged 18 years and above when shipments of the vaccine arrive. More details will be shared later.    3.    In the meantime, we encourage those who are medically eligible not to delay their vaccinations and boosters, and to take the mRNA vaccines available in our National Vaccination Programme as this will provide timely and effective protection against COVID-19.    Link (2): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702194304/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/novavax-nuvaxovid-covid-19-vaccine-authorised-for-use-in-national-vaccination-programme  --------------------------------    Other resources:  Link [1]: https://web.archive.org/web/20220617065400/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19  Link [2]: https://web.archive.org/web/20220617065642/https://www.covid.gov.sg/  Link [3]: https://web.archive.org/web/20220617065654/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/vaccination

No coding changes to the period of 18 June - 02 July 2022.  Extensive measures continue to be in place even though resumption of in-person visits to the elderly at healthcare establishments or nursing home have resumed.    ----------------------------  Quote (1):  "From 26 April 2022, in-person visits to hospitals and residential care homes will be allowed for everyone regardless of the vaccination status of patients, residents and visitors.     To protect vulnerable patients and residents from infection, hospitals and homes may continue to put in place certain safe management measures (SMMs) such as:    i. Pre-registration of visitors for patients in hospitals; and   ii. Allowing only two visitors at the bedside each time to avoid crowding in the wards/Homes       Visits to residential care homes will be capped at one hour, to allow all families of residents the opportunity to visit.      A summary of these SMMs for visitors is listed below:    Dos	 Donâts  Schedule the visits with the homes ahead of time  Exercise social responsibility by administering a COVID-19 self-test before visiting the patients/residents   Don face masks^ with good filtration capability at all times  Abide by the hospitalâs visiting hours  Visit the patients and residents if you are feeling unwell   Eat or drink in the hospital wards   Use the patientsâ toilets in the wards/Homes  Sit on patientsâ/residentsâ beds   Disturb other patients from their rest   ^These include surgical masks and reusable masks that are made of two layers of fabric.       Visits may be suspended if a residential care home is managing active COVID-19 cases. Next-of-kin of residents may approach the home for further details.      For more information, refer to MOH's press release."    Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702194539/https://www.gov.sg/article/resumption-of-in-person-visits-to-hospitals-and-residential-care-homes  -----------------------    Quote (2):  "The Ministry of Health (MOH) will further ease measures for in-person visits to hospitals and residential care homes (âHomesâ) from 26 April 2022. These include allowing in-person visits for all individuals (i.e. patients, residents and visitors) regardless of vaccination status.    2.     MOH had earlier announced the resumption of in-person visits to hospitals and Homes from 4 April 2022 for fully-vaccinated individuals and those who are medically ineligible for COVID-19 vaccination. With the further easing of community measures from 26 April 2022, there will also be adjustments to the safe management measures (SMMs) for in-person visits to hospitals and Homes.     3.     As hospitals and Homes are settings with vulnerable individuals and there is a need to protect them from infection, hospitals and Homes may continue to put in place certain SMMs such as pre-registration of visitors for patients in Hospitals, and to allow only two visitors at the bedside each time to avoid crowding in the wards/Homes.     4.     As part of social responsibility, all visitors are encouraged to administer a COVID-19 self-test prior to visiting their loved ones at the hospital or Home. Visitors should not visit their loved ones if they are feeling unwell. All visitors entering the hospital wards or Homes must don face masks with good filtration capability at all times. These include surgical masks and reusable masks that are made of two layers of fabric. Visitors are reminded not to eat or drink in the hospital wards or residential areas of the Homes, or use the toilets designated for patients/residents in the wards/Homes. They should also avoid sitting on patientsâ/residentsâ beds. They should also abide by the hospitalâs visiting hours and do not disturb other patients from their rest.    5.     Visits to Homes will be capped at one hour to allow all families the opportunity to visit their loved ones. Visitors should continue to schedule the visits with the Home ahead of time. We also seek the understanding of visitors that visits may have to be suspended if a Home is managing active COVID-19 cases. Next-of-kin of residents may approach the Home for further details.        6.     Our hospitals are still seeing a higher than usual non-COVID workload. We seek the publicâs continued cooperation to comply with the measures and remain socially responsible to keep patients/residents safe even as we take strides towards normalcy."    Link (2): https://web.archive.org/web/20220702194702/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/further-easing-of-measures-for-in-person-visits-to-hospitals-and-residential-care-homes

All Secondary Schools Years 7 to 12 and Rural Training Centres started classes on the 30 May 2022. Primary Preparation Year and Primary Schools from Years 1 to 6 will begin classes on 13 June 2022. Early Childhood Education Centres will start classes on 4 July 2022. No other updates to school opening.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220613200352/https://solomons.gov.sb/ministry-of-education-announces-reopening-of-schools/

No coding change for the period of 25 Juneâ3 July 2022. Coded *2* specifically due to continued closure of early childhood education centres. Rest of other levels have opened. Educational institutions required to have COVID-19 protocols in place including screening, social distancing, enhanced hygiene, immediate isolation of any student with COVID-like symptoms, reduced capacity to minimise crowding.     -       *On 11 May 2022, the government announced* âAll Secondary Schools Years 7 to 12 and Rural Training Centres will start classes on the 30 May 2022â¦ Primary Preparation Year and Primary Schools from Years 1 to 6 will begin classes on 13 June 2022â¦Early Childhood Education Centres will start classes on 4 July 2022â    -       *Vaccine-differentiation?*     Govt is encouraging students to vaccinate, but no vaccine-differentiation coded, as language used in govt guidelines (see Source 2 below) does not seem to state that vaccination is actually required for students to attend school, apart from a suggestion that some classes could be phased in with vaccinated students first, or alternatively, that opening could proceed one level at a time to reduce crowding.     Only strict vaccine mandate for students found in circular by the Solomon Islands National University (Source 4.), but appears to be additional precaution implemented by University management rather than government policy. Have not found evidence elsewhere that higher education institutions required by Ministry of Education or Ministry of Health to have vaccine mandate for students.    1.	Original Ministry of Education announcement of opening dates, 11 May 2022:      http://web.archive.org/web/20220711090957/https://solomons.gov.sb/ministry-of-education-announces-reopening-of-schools/     2.	Article detailing the guidelines the Ministry of Education outlined via a *radio broadcast* on 9th May 2022:    http://web.archive.org/web/20220707133810/https:/sundayisles.islesmedia.net/mehrd-advises-schools-on-key-reopening-requirements/     âThe Ministry of Education and Human Resource division and individual schools is fast-tracking the vaccination programs and make vaccines available for primary school-aged pupils between the ages of 5 to 11 years.â    âSchools with secondary students [should] also plan to phase out returning students. For Example, specific year levels phased or classes with vaccinated students only â then allow students to commence classes as soon as practicable.â    3.	16 June 2022 UNICEF article, showing that school opening schedule went ahead, and that intention is to have some screening measures in place (i.e thermometers to check temperatures).    http://web.archive.org/web/20220711152631/https://www.unicef.org/pacificislands/press-releases/over-1000-schools-solomon-islands-provided-thermometers-safe-school-re-opening     âOur secondary schools have started classes as of May 30. Primary classes will begin on the 13 of June and early childhood will begin on July 4.â    4.	Higher education: Solomon Islands National University, circular stating it has been permitted to reopen since 23 May 2022    http://web.archive.org/web/20220711154526/https://www.sinu.edu.sb/sinu-to-commence-semester-1-2022-on-may-23-2022/     âThe University Management has resolved as followsâ¦Staff and students are required to show vaccination cardsâ¦before [being] allowed entry to all SINU campuses.â

No changes.    Hotels (except for residents), bars, nightclubs and restaurants are all closed. Some restaurants are open for takeaways. Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Services, Health Advisory posted on 16 June 2022:     https://archive.ph/mmQDu    âAlthough the situation in Honiara is showing signs of a reduction in COVID-19 cases, we expect that there may be new infections reported in Honiara due to the easing of public health restrictions, opening of schools, mass gatherings and the international borders.â    âFOR EVERYONE: Practice physical distancing of at least 2 meters apart. Avoid going to areas that have a lot of people. Avoid organizing any social events attracting mass gathering.â    2. With the continued outbreak of COVID-19 in Honiara no scheduled international flights are currently operating. With the permission of the Prime Ministerâs Office and the Solomon Island Governmentâs Oversight Committee, it may be possible to enter on the Wednesday and Friday Solomon Airlines flights from Brisbane.    You must be vaccinated at least 15 days prior to arrival in Solomon Islands and you must be able to provide documentary evidence of your vaccination.    Quarantine is mandatory and is currently set at 10 days. Non-Solomon Island citizens must pay for their quarantine costs.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220624145820/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/solomon-islands/entry-requirements

No coding change for entire period of 25â30 June 2022. Coded *4* (unvaccinated) / *2* (vaccinated). Entry requirements are as follow:     1.	Must have proof of being *fully-vaccinated*. 2nd vaccine dose must have been taken at least *4 weeks* before date of travel. Unvaccinated or partially-vaccinated travellers banned; no option to test or quarantine in lieu of vaccination.    2.	Vaccinated travellers must quarantine for 6 days upon arrival. No option to test out of quarantine early.     *Additional note:* Formally, the government states that borders are closed. Even for vaccinated travellers, entry is in practice extremely restrictive, because:     1. Travellers (even fully vaccinated) must first apply for entry permission from the Prime Ministerâs Office and the Solomon Islands Government Oversight Committee.    2. Most international flights have been suspended; only one international flight route still operating to the Solomon Islands, from Brisbane, Australia. Twice weekly flight, and places are limited. Policy change. On 1 July 2022, the Solomon Islands formally reopened its borders to international travel.     Entry requirements are as follow:    1.	Vaccine requirement: Travellers 18 and older must have proof of being fully-vaccinated. Fully-vaccinated travellers no longer need to quarantine; however must show negative PCR test 72 hours before travel. The Solomon Islands authoritiesâ definition of âfully-vaccinatedâ is for the second dose to have been completed at least *4 weeks* earlier.     2.	Unvaccinated or partially vaccinated travellers still banned. Only exceptions are for: children below 18 and those with medical contraindications to being vaccinated.    Accordingly, coding change to 3/1    -	*3* (ban) for unvaccinated as borders have formally reopened.    -	*1* (screening) for vaccinated due to removal of quarantine, as vaccination certificates and PCR tests constitute forms of screening.     Sources:     1.	ABC News, reported 1 July 2022:     http://web.archive.org/web/20220708130908/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-07-01/solomon-islands-re-opens-after-china-deal/101198914     2. Announcing the news, Solomon Islands Prime Minister, Manesseh Sogavare said While quarantine will be dropped, visitors will still need to be fully vaccinated and a negative PCR test result actioned 72 hours prior to arrival.â     http://web.archive.org/web/20220712113708/https://www.solomontimes.com/news/quarantinefree-solomon-islands-to-fully-reopen-border-on-01-july/11942    3.	Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Services, posted 1 July 2022 on official Facebook page.    https://archive.ph/y1gzr     â5. Incoming International Travellers: All incoming international passengersâ¦ must produce one negative PCR test within 72 hours before travelling into the country. All incoming international passengers must be fully vaccinated except for children less than 18 years and those not eligible for vaccination due to contraindications. All incoming travellers still need to complete the pre-departure questionnaires.â     4. No coding change for the entire period of 25 Juneâ11 July 2022. Coded 1 instead 2, as while govt provides updates on some aspects of the pandemic situation, it has not updated others.     Government has issued some updated health guidance about the COVID-19 situation, such as the precautions to be taken and changes to international travel requirements, but coded 1 because it has not been updating COVID-19 statistics about testing, positive cases for some time.    Note about limitations of internet/digital sources: Solomon Islands has relatively low internet penetration compared to many other countries; some government communications may be carried out by other means. This indicator records what has been documented via internet sources.      Sources:    1.	Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Services, Health Advisories (posted on official Facebook page):    -	Health Advisory on 16 June 2022:     https://web.archive.org/web/20220708053301/https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=338325501804847&set=a.187903646847034     -	Health Advisory posted on 1 July 2022:     https://archive.ph/h1XjZ     2.	Solomon Islands govt press release about relaxation of international travel restrictions, 1 July 2022:    http://web.archive.org/web/20220706104045/https:/solomons.gov.sb/solomon-islands-lift-travel-restrictions-starting-july-1/    Lack of update for COVID-19 cases:    3.	Solomon Islands government page, archived on 11 July 2022.     *Note: neither Web Archive or Archive VN seem to be able to save figures listed on the COVID-19 dashboard when archiving the page due to some technical issues, but as of 11 July 2022, what it stated was that the figures were last updated on â30 May 2022â).    http://web.archive.org/web/20220711150300/https://solomons.gov.sb/ministry-of-health-medical-services/covid-19-updates/    Lack of reporting corroborated with:     4.	WHO situation reports for the Western Pacific states âAmerican Samoa, Mongolia, Solomon Islands did not update the number of cases due to reporting issuesâ in its two most recent reports (See page 1 of both reports).     -	22 June to 28 June 2022:     https://archive.ph/FHxy8    -	29 June to 5 July 2022:     http://web.archive.org/web/20220711124653/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/covid19/wpro-covid-sitrep/wpro-covid19-weekly-sitrep-20220706.pdf
Tests are generally available upon request.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220613201150/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

For the entire period of 25 June 2022 to 11 July 2022, coded *2*, instead of *3* because, while there is evidence that testing is available, it does not seem to meet the standard for a coding of *3* because:     1) 	In the Solomon Islands govt health advisories, testing seems to be centred on those who are *symptomatic*, rather than generally available. While US Embassy site states that non-symptomatic persons may go to 1 specific hospital in the Chinatown suburb of Honiara for tests, coding guidance states that the highest common value of policy nationwide is coded for, so not sufficient to code a *3*.    2) 	There are significant logistical/practical limitations for people to access testing generallyâ the test sites listed in the following sources seem to all be located in *Honiara*, the capital of the Solomon Islands on the island of Guadalcanal. The country is otherwise made up of 6 major islands and 900 smaller islands; does not seem to be sufficient infrastructure to make testing nationally available at code 3. Accords with foreign travel guidance from the US Embassy which states that PCR testing while available, is not easily accessible everywhere.     Sources:    1.	Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Services, posted 16 June 2022:    http://web.archive.org/web/20220708053301/https:/www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=338325501804847&set=a.187903646847034     âIf you have COVID-19 symptoms, get yourself tested at the HCC clinics.â     2.	Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Services, posted 1 July 2022:     https://archive.ph/y1gzr    âIf you experience any COVID-19 symptoms, you can get tested at any of the HCC clinics, but if your symptoms are getting worse, immediately go to the National Referral Hospital for further medical assistance.â     âThe testing can be done at Kukum Health Clinic and Rove Health Clinic on weekdays and weekends between 8.30AM and 4.30PM.â     *Note: âHCCâ refers to âHoniara City Councilâ clinics. Consists three area health centres and five rural health clinics. Note that all seem to be concentrated around the capital, on the island of Guadalcanal.     Source about locations of HCCs:      http://web.archive.org/web/20220708172609/https://honiaracitycouncil.com/index.php/health-and-environment/hcc-clinics-2/general-clinics-2/    3.	US Embassy, travel advisory: 25 June and 8 July 2022 archived versions:    -	25 June 2022:     http://web.archive.org/web/20220625093525/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     "Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Solomon Islands? Yes, but community testing is largely incident-based and testing services are not widely available in all areas of the countryâ¦"    âNon-symptomatic persons and persons who need testing services in connection with travel may obtain such services at the Ministry of Healthâs field hospital in Chinatown. Procedures for obtaining a test often change frequently; contact the Consular Agency in Honiara for the latest information.â    -	6 July 2022: Note that the section about testing for non-symptomatic persons at the Ministry of Healthâs Chinatown hospital was removed by embassy site from this update onwards. Cannot be certain whether this reflects a policy change on 6 July 2022 as page was not archived in between 25 June and 5 July 2022. Nonetheless, should not affect overall coding since highest level of testing nationally available is coded for.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220706093214/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/      -	8 July 2022:     http://web.archive.org/web/20220708131307/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/#solomon     âAre PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Solomon Islands? Yes, but community testing is largely incident-based and testing services are not widely available in all areas of the country.    Are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes, but this may require coordination on the part of the person seeking testing, especially in cases where the test is needed for travel only. The Consular Agency in Honiara can assist with arrangements for testing.â    4.	UK travel advisory, Solomon Islands, archived 11 July 2022:     https://archive.ph/CXb22#selection-1041.0-1041.205     âIt is possible to have a Covid-19 test done locally. If you require a PCR test, you can request one. You should call the Ministry of Health â Public Health Emergency Response Team.â    http://web.archive.org/web/20220711112201/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/solomon-islands/coronavirus

No new information. It is unknown if the Health Ministry is still updating information and contact tracing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220613201623/https://www.solomonstarnews.com/mhms-fail-to-update-the-countrys-covid-status/

From 25 Juneâ11 July 2022, no coding change from *1*.    Seems to be evidence of limited contact tracing, based on some government involvement in ensuring that close contacts of positive COVID-19 are monitored, tested and/or isolated, but there is insufficient evidence to show this is done comprehensively enough for every case to meet the standard for *2*.     Language in government communications suggests some degree of surveillance and mentions that âclose contactsâ are expected to be tested and/or quarantine. However, uncertain about existing contact tracing capacity and whether extent this is being done comprehensively, so conservative coding of 1 is retained.     Sources (mentions of âclose contactsâ / âcontact tracingâ):      1.	World Bank announcement about more aid allocated to assist Solomon Islandsâ pandemic response, including contact tracing: 2 May 2022.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220711082824/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2022/05/02/world-bank-increases-its-covid-19-assistance-to-solomon-islands     âThe assistance will bolster personal protective equipment supplies for front line health workers, as well as support for case detection and contact tracingâ¦â    2.	Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Services, Health Advisories:    -	Health Advisory on 16 June 2022:     https://web.archive.org/web/20220708053301/https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=338325501804847&set=a.187903646847034     -	Zoomed in version showing full advisory w/o banner blocking it:     https://archive.ph/mmQDu     âFOR CASES AND CLOSE CONTACTS: If you have COVID-19 symptoms, get yourself tested at HCC clinicsâ¦Any persons who believed to have come into close contact with a COVID-19 positive person must immediately self-quarantine at home for 6 days and get tested for COVID-19 and if they feel symptoms are getting worse, please contact National Health Emergency Operation Centreâ¦â     -	Health Advisory posted on 1 July 2022, mention of close contacts seems to focus on international travellers:     https://archive.ph/y1gzr     âINCOMING INTERNATIONAL TRAVELLERS > See bottom of poster: âIf your  [PCR test] result is positive, the following applies: You will be required to self-isolate at home for at least 7 days. Your contacts will also need to be tested to stop infection from further spreading in your household.â     3.	UK travel advisory, Solomon Islands, archived 11 July 2022:    https://archive.ph/CXb22#selection-1033.0-1037.234     âIf you think you have COVID-19 symptoms, you should remain where you are and call the Ministry of Health on (677) 23650 (Landline) or (677) 7522202 (Mobile). You will then be contacted by the Public Health Emergency Surveillance Team.â     *Note:* Another continuing difficulty mentioned in previous policy note on 14 June 2022, is that the authorities still have not updated the number of COVID-19 cases publicly for some time. The government has stated in the abovementioned health advisories that the COVID-19 situation has improved, but exact statistics do not seem to be available:     Hence not possible to deduce whether or not contact tracing capacity has been overwhelmed from recorded cases either.     4.      WHO situation reports for the Western Pacific states âAmerican Samoa, Mongolia, Solomon Islands did not update the number of cases due to reporting issuesâ in its two most recent reports (See page 1 of both reports).     -	22 June to 28 June 2022:     https://archive.ph/FHxy8    -	29 June to 5 July 2022:     http://web.archive.org/web/20220711124653/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/covid19/wpro-covid-sitrep/wpro-covid19-weekly-sitrep-20220706.pdf     *Future WHO situation reports for subsequent updates can be found here*:     http://web.archive.org/web/20220711130515/https://www.who.int/westernpacific/emergencies/covid-19/situation-reports

Coding change, to reflect stricter language issued by the Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Services pertaining to face masks. Coded 4G due to advice being to wear face masks as long as someone is outside their homes, not simply in situations where social distancing is not possible or outdoors, for example.     Source:    1.	Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Services, (MHMS) Health Advisory posted on 16 June 2022:     â[The Ministry of] Health is issuing the following advice to all residents in Honiara as well as across the country to *strictly observe COVID-19 safe measures of:*    âFor EVERYONE: Wear face masks when you are NOT in your homes.â    Links:    -	Shows entire Facebook post and that it was posted by the MHMS on 16 June 2022:     http://web.archive.org/web/20220708053301/https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=338325501804847&set=a.187903646847034     -	Zoomed in version of the same health advisory, but without the banner obscuring the bottom: https://archive.ph/mmQDu

Coding change due to more relaxed language utilised in the Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Servicesâ (MHMS) latest announcement on 1 July 2022 about the COVID-19 precautions to be observed, compared to previous announcement issued on 16 June 2022. (Wearing of face masks in some public spaces vs. wear as long as outside oneâs home).    Coded 2G because:    -	General public is âencouragedâ to wear face masks if having COVID-19 symptoms and/or in public spaces.    -	Guidance also states that for certain specified spaces such as âbusinesses houses and critical infrastructureâ and âpublic areas like marketsâ, the wearing of face masks must be observed.     Subsequent updates could check if there are further updates regarding face mask policy posted on the MHMS' Facebook page as guidance seems to be fluid/changing often.     Sources:    1.	1 July 2022, Solomon Islands Ministry of Health & Medical Services, Health Advisory. âImproved COVID-19 situation in Solomon Islandsâ:     âFor EVERYONE: Public *encouraged* to wear face masks if experiencing flu-like symptoms and/or when in public spaces.â    âFor Business Houses and Critical Infrastructure (shops, banks, restaurants etcâ¦) and public areas (markets etc)    Continue to follow and strengthen the COVID-19 safe practices at the workplace including maintaining social distancingâ¦, hand hygiene and wearing of face mask.â    -	Zoomed in version of health advisory:     https://archive.ph/y1gzr     -	Entire Facebook post:      https://archive.ph/h1XjZ     2.	Previous announcement posted on 16 June 2022 had used more restrictive language:    â[The Ministry of] Health is issuing the following advice to all residents in Honiara as well as across the country to *strictly observe COVID-19 safe measures of:*    âFor EVERYONE: Wear face masks when you are NOT in your homes.â    Links: 16 June 2022, Solomon Islands MHMS Facebook post    -	Version showing entire Facebook post with the health advisory:     http://web.archive.org/web/20220708053301/https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=338325501804847&set=a.187903646847034     -	Zoomed in version of the same health advisory, but without the banner obscuring the bottom:     https://archive.ph/mmQDu

Universal vaccination. No prioritisation between categories, government is urging everyone to get vaccinated or to take their booster shots if they have already completed the initial doses. Royal Thai Government to further ease the nationwide COVID-19 controls by expanding the colour-coded zones to three: The Pilot Tourist Areas or blue zone, the Surveillance Areas or green zone, and the Areas under Stringent Surveillance or yellow zone.    CCSA said that zones marked âyellowâ will continue to have restrictions, meaning that they [establishments such as nightclubs, bars, pubs, karaoke bars and massage parlours] will not be allowed to reopen until further announcement.    Coded as 2T due to stringent restrictions in yellow zones.     Tatnews: https://archive.ph/6jP6A  LifestyleAsia: https://archive.ph/i8vjg

Royal Thai Government to further ease the nationwide COVID-19 controls by expanding the colour-coded zones to three: The Pilot Tourist Areas or blue zone, the Surveillance Areas or green zone, and the Areas under Stringent Surveillance or yellow zone.    Peaceful mass gatherings or large-scale events are allowed to take place in the green and blue zones under communicable disease control guidelines, while in the yellow zone the number of attendees must not exceed 1,000 or at 75% of the capacity for sports events.    Coded as 1T due to limited capacity for yellow zones.     Tatnews: https://archive.ph/6jP6A

People can move from one area to another. At-risk individuals are advised against unnecessary travel, but still coded as 0 due to very limited recommendation. Upon arriving in Thailand, all travellers must undergo entry screening, including body temperature check, and present the required documents to the Immigration/Health Control officer to carry out the checks.    The vaccinated travellers will then be allowed entry and are free to go anywhere in the kingdom.   Unvaccinated/not fully vaccinated travellers will need to upload proof of a negative Covid-19 result from an RT-PCR test or professional ATK within 72 hours of travel via the Thailand Pass system.    Tatnews: https://archive.ph/gBYpT

Some regions, such as Phuket, have eased mask mandate:   mandatory mask-wearing is exempted when people are eating or drinking, showing their faces to confirm their identities to state authorities, exercising in an open area, and while at a beach, a public park and other places where people can stay at least two metres apart.    However, not applied to the whole country, so coded as 3T.     Bangkok Post: https://archive.ph/HTpYE

A second State of Emergency, following the Hunga-Tonga Hunga-Haâapai volcanic eruption, has also been renewed until 8am on 3 July 2022. To effectively control and control risks, after a comprehensive assessment of the epidemic situation, the current epidemic prevention measures such as wearing masks will be maintained from July 1.   Business premises and public areas (including transportation): Strict compliance with body temperature measurement, strengthening of environmental cleaning, employee health management, and immediate response to confirmed incidents.  Stores, supermarkets, and markets: According to the epidemic prevention measures in business premises/public areas, crowd control is not required; open for tasting.    https://archive.ph/E47eC

II. Commercial business venues and public venues (including transportation) should take temperatures, enhance disinfection of premises, carry out health management among staff, and implement timely responses to the occurrence of confirmed cases.    III. Stores, supermarkets, and markets: follow epidemic prevention measures for such commercial business venues/public venues; crowd control is not required, and food sampling is allowed.    IV. Taiwan High-Speed Rail (THSR), Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA), intercity buses, and ships/ferries (except for designated dining areas), and domestic flights: consuming food and beverages is allowed inside a vehicle (train, ship or aircraft).    V. Dining venues should: rigorously take temperatures and provide hand washing and disinfection equipment; toasting each table is not allowed at banquets. Venues that violate the abovementioned measures are subject to penalties according to applicable laws and required to make remedies within a given time period; those who fail to do so will not be allowed to offer dine-in services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220707094754/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/kz90Fw57jVfgKEGAYMqK3A?typeid=158

Considering that the epidemic prevention regulations have reached a milestone and that local governments need to make better use of religious epidemic prevention manpower in response to the current epidemic, from now on, the above-mentioned events can be held without the need to submit epidemic prevention plans in advance, as long as the organisers are able to take all epidemic prevention measures and manage the events themselves.    https://archive.ph/Htakm

Travel ban on foreign nationals  Taiwan has in place a temporary ban on foreign nationals entering Taiwan. However there are certain exceptions, as follows.    The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has announced that, from 13 April 2022, foreign relatives of Taiwan citizens and foreign residents in Taiwan, with the exception of migrant workers, are now able to apply for a special entry permit to enter Taiwan. Applicants will be required to complete an online visa application form and to submit the required documentation to the Bureau of Consular Affairs (BOCA) for consideration.    In addition, exceptions apply for the following groups: ARC/APRC/Gold Card holders, business travellers, foreign spouses of Taiwan passport holders and their children under the age of 20, foreign relatives of Taiwan passport holders, international students and foreign professors and researchers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220707095518/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

COVID-19 Testing:    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Taiwan?  Yes.  For a nationwide list of COVID testing centers, please see here under the heading âDesignated Hospital List for out-of-pocket COVID-19 PCR testing .â  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day?  Yes.  Self-pay COVID-19 test is widely available at hospitals throughout Taiwan.  An English test report is available after 48 hours or less.  Test report can be delivered only by in-person pick up.  Cost of testing as listed by the hospitals varies from NTD 3,500 to NTD 8,000 (USD 127â286)  If you are currently in Taiwan and believe that you may have symptoms of COVID-19, please visit the Centers for Disease Control website  or call the Communicable Disease Prevention and Reporting Hotline at 1922 for information  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to CDCâs requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID test, please review CDCâs website .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220707102401/https://www.ait.org.tw/covid-19-information/
COVID-19 contact tracing self-reporting system to be launched on May 1 to simplify contact tracing procedures of health departments    https://archive.ph/txXCW

Contact tracing requirements in Taiwan  The Central Epidemic Command Centre (CECC) has announced the launch of a new self-reporting contact tracing system for members of the public who have contracted COVID-19 locally in Taiwan.    Any individual who receives a positive COVID-19 PCR test will receive a text message from the local authorities which advises on their positive test result and a link to the new self-reporting portal. You will then be required to report your condition, recent contact history and whether you require any medical assistance by logging on to the online system and following the instructions provided. Once completed, you will then receive instructions from the system advising on your quarantine and any further testing requirements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220707095518/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

The current regulations on wearing masks remain unchanged, except for exceptions. You should still wear a mask when you go out:  (1) When singing, you must always wear a mask.  (2) Masks are not required in the following situations, but you should carry or prepare masks with you. If you have related symptoms or you cannot maintain social distance with unspecified objects, you should still wear masks:  1. Indoor and outdoor sports.  2. Take individual/group photos indoors and outdoors.  3. Drive by yourself, with family members living in the same car, or those who do not share the same car.  4. During the formal shooting or progress of conversational work or activities such as live broadcast, video recording, hosting, reporting, speeches, speeches, and lectures.  5. Agriculture, forestry, fishery and animal husbandry workers work in open spaces (such as fields, fish farms, mountains and forests).  6. Activities in mountains and forests (including forest recreation areas) and seaside.  7. In hot/cold springs, ovens, spa facilities, saunas, steam rooms, water activities and other occasions where the mask is likely to get wet.    https://archive.ph/E47eC

I. Mask rules remain unchanged; masks are required when outside except for the situations listed below.    a. Masks remain mandatory when singing.  b. In the following situations, people are not required to wear a mask, but they should carry a mask with them or have a mask ready for use. Masks are still required if COVID-19 symptoms are present and social distancing cannot be maintained with non-specific persons.    1. When exercising outdoors or indoors;  2. When taking individual/group photos indoors or outdoors;  3. When driving alone or with live-in family members;  4. When livestreaming, filming, moderating an event, reporting, delivering remarks, giving a speech, lecturing, or during activities or events involving conversations with others;  5. When people in the agriculture, forestry, fishing, and animal husbandry sectors work in open spaces (such as farm fields, fish ponds, forests, and mountains);  6. When people are in forests/mountains (including forest recreation areas) and on the beach;  7. When people are in hot/cold springs, dry sauna rooms, spas, steam rooms, saunas, during water activities, or in venues where masks can get wet easily.    c. Masks may be removed when consuming food/beverages outside.  d. Masks may be temporarily removed in venues or during activities (e.g. art performers performing a show, film crews/TV news anchors when filming, and athletes, and referees participating in sports competitions) that comply with the CECC's or competent authority's epidemic prevention and control rules.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220707094754/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/kz90Fw57jVfgKEGAYMqK3A?typeid=158

The Taiwan vaccination programme started in March 2021 and is using the AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna and Medigen vaccines. British nationals resident in Taiwan are eligible for vaccination. The Taiwanese authorities have released an online reservation system for booking a COVID-19 vaccination appointment in Taiwan. Individuals who have received two doses of a COVID-19 vaccine will be eligible to receive a third dose of a COVID-19 vaccine 12 weeks after the date they received their second dose. Vaccine priority groups and other criteria will apply.  The Central Epidemic and Command Centre (CECC) has announced that from 2 May 2022, children aged between 5 to 11 years old will now be able to receive a COVID-19 vaccine in Taiwan.    https://archive.ph/awvKr

The Taiwan vaccination programme started in March 2021 and is using the AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna and Medigen vaccines. British nationals resident in Taiwan are eligible for vaccination.    The Taiwanese authorities have released an online reservation system for booking a COVID-19 vaccination appointment in Taiwan. Foreign nationals who hold an Alien Resident Card (ARC) and National Health Insurance (NHI) card will be required to complete an online form and provide their contact information to register. Foreign nationals who do not hold a National Health Insurance card will be required to provide their ARC UI number and passport number in order to register. The local health department in the applicantâs area will contact the individual once an appointment has been scheduled. Vaccine priority groups and other criteria will apply.    The Central Epidemic and Command Centre (CECC) has announced that from 2 May 2022, children aged between 5 to 11 years old will now be able to receive a COVID-19 vaccine in Taiwan.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220707095518/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

On June 24, the Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) announced that it will loosen visitation management measures for residential long-term care facilities nationwide, effective from June 24. Key points are listed below.    I. Eased visitation management measures for residential long-term care facilities nationwide:  A. The previous ban on visitors in residential long-term care facilities in Taipei City, New Taipei City, Keelung City, Taoyuan City, Kaohsiung City, and Hualien County, with certain exceptions, will be lifted, and residential long-term care facilities across Taiwan can conditionally allow visitors.  B. Visitors must present a negative result from a self-paid COVID-19 test (including at-home rapid test) taken on the day of their visit. Visitors can be exempted from screening if they have received a COVID-19 booster shot for at least 14 days or if they have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and have met the criteria for release from isolation, and 15 days to three months have passed since the onset of symptoms or the positive test (applicable to asymptomatic individuals).    II. Vaccine dose requirements for individuals accompanying residents/staying overnight:  A. The criterion for COVID-19 test exemptions for individuals accompanying residents/overnight visitors will be changed to receiving a COVID-19 booster shot at least 14 days ago. Individuals can be exempted from testing if they have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and released from isolation, and 15 days to three months have passed since the date of the onset of symptoms or the positive test (applicable to asymptomatic individuals).  B. Individuals accompanying residents who have not received a COVID-19 booster dose for at least 14 days should present a negative result from a self-paid COVID-19 test (including at-home rapid test) taken on the day of their visit; those staying overnight with residents should take a self-paid screening test (including at-home rapid test) every seven days if they haven't received their booster doses for at least 14 days, and no one else can fill in for them.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220707103746/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/Nqx8qjwIIA193jeH1-n9kQ?typeid=158

As of 07 June the following recommendations have been made:  Torres group (Hiu, Toga, Loh, Tequa, Metoma) Vanua Lava and Gaua to move to Recovery Level 1 and the rest of the Banks group (Merelava, Merig, Ureparapara) to remain at COVID-19 Alert Level 1. Mota and Motalava to move to Alert level 3.  Tanna and Aneityum â COVID 19 Alert Level 3 and Aniwa and Futuna to remain at COVID-19 Alert Level 1. Erromango is now at Recovery level 3  Pentecost to move to Recovery Level 1 and Ambae and Maewo are now at COVID 19 Alert Level 3.  All the islands of Malampa province remain at COVID-19 Alert Level 1.  Efate and its offshore islands to remain at Recovery Level 1 and Epi is now at Alert Level 3. Tongoa and Shepherds group (Makira, Buninga, Mataso, Emae, Tongariki) to remain at COVID 19 Alert Level 1.  Santo and its offshore islands and Malo Island to move to Recovery Level 1    Closure of educational facilities. Closure of educational facilities may be required to keep staff and students, limit interaction between students, prevent transmission to family members and help prevent the spread of COVID-19 in the community.  COVID-19 is contained at Alert Level 0 and Alert Level 1, and there is no restriction to educational facilities at these levels.  At Alert Level 2, educational facilities may be required to close in the affected islands. Closure of non-essential services. Closure of non-essential services may be required to keep workers safe, limit interaction with customers and help prevent the spread of COVID-19. Entry to Vanuatu  Borders are closed to non-residents. Air Vanuatu run occasional scheduled repatriation flights from Auckland, Brisbane and Noumea for Vanuatu citizens and permanent residents. Places on these flights need to be pre-approved by the Vanuatu authorities. Eligible travellers from countries apart from Australia, New Zealand, New Caledonia and Fiji must quarantine at a government-approved location at their own expense for 7 days and are required to return a negative rapid antigen test (RAT) result on Day 6 of their quarantine stay before they may be released.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220625094145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/vanuatu/entry-requirements

Entry to Vanuatu  Borders are closed to non-residents. Air Vanuatu run occasional scheduled repatriation flights from Auckland, Brisbane and Noumea for Vanuatu citizens and permanent residents. Places on these flights need to be pre-approved by the Vanuatu authorities. Eligible travellers from countries apart from Australia, New Zealand, New Caledonia and Fiji must quarantine at a government-approved location at their own expense for 7 days and are required to return a negative rapid antigen test (RAT) result on Day 6 of their quarantine stay before they may be released.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220625094145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/vanuatu/entry-requirements

Before Travel to Vanuatu    Negative RAT or negative PCR or for an older infection a positive RAT/PCR within 8 days  All travelers to Vanuatu aged 2 years and over must provide at check-in for the flight to Vanuatu evidence of:    Negative COVID-19 PCR test result for a sample taken between 24 to 72 hours before the scheduled time of departure, OR  Negative COVID-19 supervised certified Rapid Antigen Test (RAT) result for a sample taken within 24 hours of the scheduled time of departure, OR  Positive COVID-19 supervised certified RAT or PCR test result from a previous infection for a sample taken at least 8 days but no more than 2 months before the scheduled date of departure, OR  A recovery letter from a medical doctor stating that the traveller has recovered from a COVID-19 infection within the last 2 months and is no longer infectious  A supervised certified RAT test is one for which the collection and evaluation is performed by a healthcare professional (i.e. at a pharmacy, laboratory, hospital or medical center) with a certificate issued.    The evidence of a negative test result may need to be provided in advance of travel and must be made available at check-in for the flight to Vanuatu and upon arrival in Vanuatu. At the airports, this should be shown in hard copy on paper or displayed on a smart device.    If there are one or more connecting flights to Vanuatu, the departure time and date should be considered to be from the initial travel origin for the first flight. If flights are delayed but departure occurs within 72 hours of the scheduled departure time then another negative RAT or PCR is not required.    Travel clearance  Information on travel clearance should be sought from the Vanuatu Department of Immigration. A new online travel system is being developed by the Department of Immigration and updates will be communicated through that other avenue.    Travel approval from the Ministry of Health is no longer required before you can board at your original port of departure. The Vanuatu Electronic Traveller System (VETS) is not being used from 29 June 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220712102706/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/travelling-to-vanuatu/travelers-to-vanuatu

Get tested if you are sick . In most cases, COVID-19 causes mild symptoms including a runny nose, sore throat, cough and fever. It can be more severe for some people and can lead to pneumonia or breathing difficulties. These symptoms do not necessarily mean you have COVID-19. The symptoms are similar to other illnesses that are much more common, such as colds and flu.    At Alert Level 0 and Alert Level 1 anyone working in a quarantine facility or at the border should be tested if they have symptoms.  At Alert Level 2 and Alert Level 3 the Ministry of Health will provide additional testing facilities in affected islands and areas and anyone with symptoms should get tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625091239/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/updates/vanuatu-outbreak-alert-system

When instructed, âcheck-inâ to venues. If a case of COVID-19 is identified in Vanuatu, we will rapidly try to find everyone who they have been in close contact with (âclose contactsâ), as well as those that were in the same venue or event at the same time but who is at lower risk than a close contact (âcasual contactâ). To enable this, everyone will need to check-in to certain venues by entering their contact details in a registration form on entry. Eligible venues will have signage informing you that you need to register on entry. Once implemented, âChecking-inâ to venues will be required at all levels    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625091239/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/updates/vanuatu-outbreak-alert-system

Wear a mask.A face covering helps stop droplets spreading when someone speaks, laughs, coughs or sneezes. This includes someone who has COVID-19 but feels well or has no obvious symptoms. Face coverings are particularly useful when physical distancing is not possible. When using fabric facemasks, ensure they meet the minimum technical standards (3 layers) as recommended by the Ministry of Health.    At Alert Level 1, everyone working in quarantine facilities will be required to wear a mask.  At Alert Level 2 and Alert Level 3 masks will be required to be worn when out of the home. This includes when using shared cooking or bathroom facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625091239/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/updates/vanuatu-outbreak-alert-system

From 21 June 2021, COVID-19 vaccination was opened to all adults 18 years old and over (with a continued focus on priority groups). Vaccination roll-out is ongoing in all six provinces of the country. Booster shots are planned for administration to priority groups in 2022.    In Port Vila, vaccination is being conducted at George Pompidou Vaccination Center, with mobile teams operating elsewhere. The Center operates from 8.30am to 3.30pm on Monday to Friday (except on public holidays).    The Ministry of Health is working to identify options for additional vaccines to enable full vaccination of the eligible population of Vanuatu.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220625171646/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/vaccination/information
